number of helpful: 372 of 406 people (92%) found this review helpful43 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 12, 2014
												This is hands down, no lies or embellishments made, the best game I have ever played. Perhaps my experiences are colored by a long lifetime of loving this game, but I have never found something that interests me more, that I can just sit down and play a few hours of and craft a life-story for my character, an entire persona. It's simple really, you are a pirate and the wide open world of the 1600's Carribean is yours for the plucking. The graphics are out of date, the controls are simplistic, and your crew will always get upset no matter how many famous pirates and ships you sink, steal, or scuttle. You can't win, mainly because there is no victory condition. You can save your family, you can get married, you can become the deadliest and most notorious man on the high seas, it's all up to you what you do, who you become, which beach you get marooned on, I love it, I've lived years loving it, I can't recommend this game enough. It isn't for hardcore gamers, don't come in looking to get the highest score, play to relax, it'll work, you'll love it, just, just play the damn game.

content:
Posted: September 4, 2015
												I guess this game just tickled me right because I loved everything about it. It would be most accurate to describe this game as a collection of mini-games combined into a single experience. There's the land battle mini-game, the ship-combat mini-game, the dancing mini-game, and the fencing mini-game, all connected together by a sailing overworld. I hear a lot of people like the fencing and ship battles but dislike the land-battles and dancing. I liked all of it. And I don't often play musical rhythm games, either.I'll admit also that playing the whole game has a certain amount of nostalgia appeal for me as well. I played the original in the form of a demo when I was a kid, never got the chance to play the whole thing. Thus closes a previously unfinished chapter of my childhood here.

number of helpful: 268 of 293 people (91%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 22, 2014
												If you’re an older gamer, then you are more than likely familiar with Sid Meier’s Pirates. It was one of the first games to give you truly open-ended gameplay – you were free to sail under any flag, change allegiances, be a merchant or a pirate … the Caribbean was an open sea for you to explore. The gameplay was pretty straightforward, but it had an engaging quality to it that would cause you to lose yourself in the game for hours on end. Now the game has received a much overdue update and its basic design has withstood the test of time – the game is just as much fun as it ever was, if not more so.The premise of the game is simple: you’re a young buccaneer captain out to make your fortune on the Spanish Main. You’re also out to avenge the capture of you family and rescue them from indentured servitude, but it is really up to you whether or not you want to pursue their rescue. The game will rate your performance more highly if you do, but you can certainly simply concentrate on becoming a feared pirate and leave your family to fend for themselves. The game does not oblige you to do anything.Politics plays a large role in the game as it did in the Caribbean in the 17th Century. The four nations vying for dominance in the region constantly shift allegiances and move in and out of states of war. As an enterprising captain you need to take advantage of this and always be on the look out for new opportunities.The animations are detailed and you’ll see your sails react to the wind as you tack or come about, the wake kicked up by your ship, and even dolphins who come to play in that wake. While sailing the seas you’ll encounter other ships and as you approach you’ll see the flag of their nationality and the ship’s class. Battles on deck are abstracted to a sword dual between you and the enemy captain. You can select a rapier, long sword, or cutlass with which to fight, each of which is a trade off to some degree between speed and defense. You have three attack moves to choose from and a defensive move to counter each.The cities in the game are for far more than sacking. As you sail the Caribbean you’ll see the relative size of each city and be able to tell its relative wealth from the condition of the flag that flies above the town.When in town you have several locations that you can visit. Each town also has a shipwright who can repair your battle damage, buy your captured ships, or in some cases provide upgrades to your hull, sails, or cannons to aid your ship’s performance in battle. Speaking of treasure, it wouldn’t be a pirate game without buried treasure. At the lower difficulty levels maps are always complete and well-marked and it is simply a question of going to the right location and picking up your prize. At higher levels things get a bit trickier as you often have to make do with map fragments and must search for specific landmarks like an arched rock or a clump of dead trees to find the buried booty.Overall Pirates has that hard to pinpoint addictive quality to it that will keep you coming back. Hours will disappear as you strive to complete one more raid or get your next promotion. It’s a magical quality that’s missing in most games, and one that will keep you coming back to Pirates as other games come and go.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
												This is the best Pirate RPG I've had the pleasure of playing, and it's amazing in how it fools you desperately. You have this sort of "drive" to get a VERY good ship. So naturally, "Size Matters" kick in. You take your ♥♥♥♥♥♥ sloop, attack a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ galleas and voila you think! Your ship can now house 32 cannons with a 200 man crew (I believe.) So you take your Galleas, you name it something like "Josephine" and drive it around. You keep your sloop with you or discard it, perhaps even sell it and you feel like Captain Jack Freaking Sparrow. Then you go into a tavern and the lovely barmaid informs you that there's a War Frigate out to kill ya, so you capture that. You now have 50 cannons, possible 400 crew, cargo hold of 128 ton and feel invincible. Then you drive your ship around and feel like the King of the World. That's how it usually is, and seems to be how most people play this game. It's the wrong way. You start out, you take your Sloop and find a War Canoe. They can be found amongst the savage natives of the Caribbean. You board it with your sloop and acquire it. The next thing you do is to go into town and sell your cannons and your sloop. And everything that's not food. You wont be needing it. You have your War Canoe. You then go to the tavern and recruit the 48 people wanting to join you. Voila, full crew. And you have your War Canoe. The War Canoe is in fact the best ship in the entire game. "But Sir, what about when the English deploy a Ship of the Line to take me out?" You board it. They shoot at you? Well guess what, I hope your Mother taught you how to weave, for you'll be weaving your way around the cannonfire into the Ship. You board it at once the fight starts. If it's too much for you or you take a hit or two, you're in the fastest ship in the game. Turn around, sail away. Nothing can catch up to you. Oh no you wont have cannons, who needs it? Sugar, spice, goods? With your crew of 50 whatever you plunder from the ships in gold is way more than what you'd normally be due. You take your War Canoe, which you'll name something like "Arrow" or "Emma" and ram that thing into whatever comes your way. It's the best ship. Here's why:-You can bypass ship battles. This means more gold for you. And I personally found them tedious-Boarding is more manly-Your ship is the fastest in the game. Get a quest to escort a Governor from Mexico to Florida? Takes you 4 minutes. -Hunting some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ that keeps your family hostage? Like hell he can outsail you.-Smaller Crew means fewer mouths to feed, and more gold for you when you divide the plunder.-With a big ship, you'll either shoot something dead while taking damage or see them board you without difficulty. Why be the prey? 10/10 game would make my own War Canoe.

Posted: November 19, 2014
												I played the original Sid Meier's Pirates! on Commodore 64 in 1985.  I broke many-a-joystick trying to sail against the wind.  Good times.  This game brought back all of those memories in a massive flood.  I thoroughly enjoyed plundering all sorts of ships, I like the land combat, and the storyline gave the game something to work towards rather than just a blast-and-hack pirate game.  The nostalgia effect was strong, and for die-hard, long-time gamers such as myself, this is a must-have.  Best three bucks I ever spent.

												If you ever get the chance to buy this game at a reasonable price, for instance in the recent humble bundle sale or gamefly.co.uk sale, DO IT! This game is my childhood so perhaps I'm biased, but for the 2,50€ I paid for this game it's a steal.Although relatively short, you'll finish it in around 15 hours if you don't waste too much time, Sid Meier's Pirates! includes a variety of era's to play (1600-20, 20-40, ... , 80-1700) each with a different twist to it. Posted: March 19, 2015
												Beyond the nostalgia I feel for this game, it is genuinely an incredibly well made game for its time. Open world (ocean) exploration, controll over your fleet and what kind of ships are in it, as well as multiple quest lines and missions to do (become the most notorious pirate, get with a governors daughter, save your long lost family etc). The combat is easy to get the hang of (it's basically just timed events, but with combos) but if you pick a more difficult playing mode it legitimately can be excruciatingly dificult, so you can't get bored with it really as long as you keep yourself on a game difficulty that works for you. I deeply recommend this game, especially when it's on sale.

content:
Posted: June 2, 2015
												TLDR: I really liked this game, and it really surprised me. So I bought this game on a whim when it was on sale, a dollar or so. Added it to my steam queue figuring maybe I'd play it when I had nothing better to do. Fast forward a year later and lo and behold, I had nothing better to do, so I booted it up on a whim. I figured it would be a monumental waste of time. This was half right, however not the half I was expecting. This game is somewhat repetitive, sure. But it is deeply satisfying, and it took me a while to figure out why. You can play all kinds of naval war simulators, or sword battle fighting games that are much better than the mechanics of this game. But this had a depth come out of these simple mechanics that made the game a really cool experience. Moreover, this game fairly effectively makes you want to pursue non-combative game play. I'd never given much thought into wanting to dance in a video game before, but it was probably the most fun I'd had in a game, and it wasn't just the novelty. It's easy to make yourself feel like your character has a vested romantic relationship with the woman he is wooing and want to succeed in impressing her with your awesome button pressing skills. It kind of made me want to learn how to dance in real life.Also, did I mention that you get to be a pirate?

Posted: December 8, 2013
												It's the best pirate game I've ever played. It's also one of the very few pirate games I've ever played, so I dunno if my review will count for much. Surprisingly addicting open-world pirate game where you can go out and do random stuff, like rescue your family from this villain, go treasure hunting, attack other ships and/or settlements, acquire goods from one port and selling it at another port (trading), and even wooing (and eventually marrying) a random daughter of a govenor. There's fun mini games (although lots of people hate the dancing one) and you basically play until you grow too old to continue pirating. Keep watch of the morale of your crew at sea or they may end up deserting you!Only bad thing I found with the game is that the main character whom you play as doesn't look manly enough for my liking, and while I like the dancing mini-games, it tends to go on for too long. If it was a shorter mini-game, it would've been much better.

number of helpful: 69 of 82 people (84%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
Sid Meier's Pirates! is a pirate adventure game. After a mutiny that put you at the helm of your own ship, you and your pirate crew arrive in the Caribbean to find fortune as you seek to avenge your family from those that did it wrong.Pros: Every tropes you ever saw about pirates are there: build your reputation and ranking with the four European factions, while also dealing with the clergy, the natives and the pirate community, compete against the most notorious pirates in history while using pieces of maps to find their buried treasure or the lost cities of gold, do ship-to-ship combat against raider, merchant, military or other pirate vessels, flirt with the governor's daughters by impressing her in the ballroom. The game is easy to pick up regardless of difficulty level, navigating, ship-to-ship combat and swordplay are simple. 27 different type of ships sail the sea, any of which can be captured, each with different storage and crew capacity, optimal wind angle, speed and turning speed. Ship-specific upgrades are available at various ports, capturing ships might get get you permanent specialists for your crew, a variety of items can be purchased in taverns. The graphics are bright and colorful and animations are smooth.Cons: The graphics are showing their age. Sid Meier's Pirates! borders on the casual game, as it's basically a collection of multiple mini-games: fighting, dancing, ship-to-ship combat, swordplay, city sacking, all mini-games with little depth. City conquering strategy is extremely simplified, and the game lacks any realism of the hardships of being at sea. Capturing ships will become repetitive after a few playthrough. The map is always the same, varied only by the chosen timeline or occasional city conquest of a rival European faction.Verdict: ★★★☆☆ - It's up to youOverall, this is a fun game, and that's all it aims to be: fun. It isn't a seafaring simulator, it isn't an action sword-fighter, it isn't a trade simulator and definitively isn't a strategy game. If you're looking for a nice, easy and fun game worth its price, then I'll recommend you give Sid Meier's Pirates! a try!—————————————————————————This was just my opinion.If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up, and feel free to check out more of my (purely opinionated) reviews.

content:
Posted: May 31, 2015
												WOW. Sid Meier's Pirates! A true classic, in almost every way imagineable. I've played a lot more of this way back when.Gameplay:+Lovely fun.+The free choice of the game is awesome. Be a ruthless pirate, a mercenary, a trader, a romantic, a dueller, or all of them.+Faction system and promotions are very well done.+There's a ♥♥♥♥♥on to do, and I never feel bored.+Different ships for different playstyles.+2nd game has advanced startup.+Pretty large map.+The perfect amount of water.+Get married, own land, dance, essentially Capitalism Simulator 1660. Sort of.+-The easiest difficulty has wind always facing west.+-Non-customizable character, besides from items purchased from travellers, and that's barely customization. Mods, though.+-Sneaking into town is average.-You can't destroy enemy strongholds by sea by spamming the Spacebar.9/10Story:+It's alright, something out of a 19th century novelist or Hollywood.+Your family was captured, and, in the course of the game, you must rescue them and  find the man who wronged your family and essentially harm him.+Lots of side quests.+-Voice acting is suiting, but doesn't hit the right cords often.+-The health mechanic is interesting, but ruins a good game when you retire not fufilling a lot.7/10Graphics:+For it's time, great.+It has surprisingly aged well, for a game made 11 years ago.+The water looks nice, even on Intel graphics cards.+Intel Graphic Card friendly.-Some land spots look a bit... Meh.8/10Music/Sound:+Kickass.+There's music to dancing, swordfighting, naval combat, trading, the tavern... A whole bunch. And it's well done.+Sound is alright, too.+-Hero's voice.-The govenors sound like they're the High-Class Extrodinare, while true, somewhat annoying.7/10Concensus: I give Pirates! an 8.5/10. A gaming classic, that has truly aged well. Pick it up if you havn't.DayZ Review Gimmick: I was a bad dancer. The govenor's daughter turned me down. She laughed. I laughed when I sacked her town and gave it to the English. 8.5/10chuburn

content:
Posted: July 29, 2014
												BEST ABOUT IT:  The open ended nature, sailing around picking on ships that outclass you, and managing your fleet and supplies. WORST ABOUT IT:  The quicktime event dancing and fencing scenes are downright awful and the mere thought of them is usually enough to prevent me from playing this game.GAMEPLAY:  You start by choosing a country to side with and a small sloop in that chosen country's port.  You can get some info and supplies from that port and then you're off to sail around the Caribbian.  The ship controls feel fantastic, working with or against the wind, and there is strategy in what type of cannon shot you fire, round to damage a hull, chain to damage the sails, and grape to take out crew.  You also need to buy or raid supplies to keep your crew from a mutiny.CONTROLS:  Steering your ship and firing the cannons is very satisfying.  However the UI and map screens are clunky and seem like from an age prior to when this game was released.  The QTE cut scenes are obnoxious and repetitive but they can mostly be avoided altogether.STORY:  You play as a young pirate who is trying to rescue his family and defeat some marquis villain.  This is a sandbox game so you’ll be creating your own story for the most part.  There's no way to customise your character other than your name and some stat bonuses (1 perk at the start and others with items), but you can captain any ship you can get your hands on and deck it out with upgrades.GRAPHICS:  The main graphics look Caribbean and still mostly hold up today and are certainly functional, but the cut scenes look dated.  You have to use your imagination a bit.  The highest screen resolution is 1152 x 864 and no widescreen.  It looks ok though, and there are ways to force the resolution if you want.PERFORMANCE:  Ran smoothly for me and I didn't encounter any problems.SOUND:  Excellent.  The sounds of the waves, creaking of the wooden ships, and shouts of your crew are some of the first things that come to mind thinking of this game.  I’m not a fan of the Simlish spoken dialect though.  The music is fitting and sets the cartoony pirate mood well.REPLAYABILITY:  Replay doesn’t get any better than this game.  However I haven’t actually finished the story yet, it's just fun to sail around and do your own thing.SIMILAR TO:  I don’t know, the Sims 2 mixed with Grand Theft Auto 1 and Port Royale?RECOMMENDED PURCHASE PRICE:  I don't see this on sale often but $10 is reasonable.Sid Meier’s PiratesFiraxis Games 2004 (remake of 1987 original)RATING:  75/100

												I downloaded this game with the Sid Meiers humble bundle. I wasn't originially very excited for it, because I had only bought the bundle for the civ games but after playing this game for a few hours, I'm happy it was included. The game is a little confusing at first, but after playing for a little it becomes a bit easier to understand. However, I still have no idea what the main objective is besides the fact that you're a pirate looking to save his family (that much is clear from the intro). As far as I know you don't have to follow the main quests or any of that really, you can just plunder riches or charm governors daughter until retirement. After about 3.5 hours, I'm still not bored with the pirate life. I still haven't fully discovered all of the game, but the parts I have discovered are what makes this game addicting. I fully recommend this to anyone who enjoys strategy or even just pirates.

Posted: September 25, 2016
												Do NOT be fooled by my 12 hours of gameplay. I used to play this game endlessly after it came out. If you love games that are all about player choice, then this is absolutely for you. Want to be a swashbuckling badass and go about destroying the caribbean in a hellfire of cannonshot and steel? Want to be a simple trader, escaping your past and aiming to lead a simple life of commerce? Want to be a hero, save your family, get the girl, and slap about the hapless spaniards? Do it, do it, and do it.Naval battles, sword fights, dancing, stealth, trade...it's all here and you can do whatever the b***h you like. The game's aesthetic is less "reality" and more "disney cartoon" which makes the atmosphere of the game that much more delightful to partake in however you please.Super replayable, full of player choice and a delight to both look at and immerse yourself in; this game has aged incredibly well. I want to join the throng that cries for an HD remake but...this game is a masterpiece as it is. No need for a newer version. TL;DR Player choice, high replay value, excellent and varied gameplay.

content:
Posted: October 7, 2014
												This is a fun, casual game.  It is not, by any means, deep, but it's still enjoyable to mess around with.  You play the game as a pirate in the Caribbean pre-Johnny Depp.  You can play the game during various historical settings which basically have the effect of changing how much variety there is in terms of the different national factions.  The later you set the game, the more likely you'll see major French, Dutch, and English ports.  By contrast, in the earlier settings, it's far more Spanish-dominated.  This can have an effect on how you play the game.  With more factions, you have more ability to behave like a true pirate, sinking or taking vessels of various factions, and then doing the same to whomever they're at war with (and they're always at war with someone...).  When it's just the Spanish, you have to try playing a minigame where you sneak into the Spanish port, risking imprisonment.  Speaking of the minigames, they're generally good fun, if occasionally repetitive and annoying.  The dancing in particular can get tedious, but at least you're usually well rewarded.  As I mentioned, the game isn't particularly deep.  It's not as if you're running a wooden ship simulator.  The game's graphics are dated, but acceptable.  They were fortunately done in a "cartoony" style, so they age a bit better than supposedly cutting-edge visuals from the same era (2004), which now fall squarely into "uncanny valley" territory.  Anyway, it's a good game, and usually available on Steam for dirt cheap.  You'll definitely get your $2-5 worth out of this title.

content:
Posted: March 9
-Quick Review-Sid Meier's Pirates! was developed by Firaxis Games and released Jul 11, 2005.Sid Meier's Pirates! is a part-strategy game, part-managment game, part-sailing/naval simulator game, part barbie-dance game, part RPG, part open-world-game, and even has stealth and questing elements.-Video Review-


YouTube™ Video: Sid meiers Pirates - AHOY! - Atratzu Reviews 

			Views: 442		

			AVAST! All hands on deck! Cap'n Atratzu presiding! All ye land lubber's an' scurvy dogs will be watching this here video.		

-Detailed breakdown review-Story: The story starts off with the protagonist (Your name goes here) as a little boy, and his family is abducted by corrupt noblemen. Then fast forward to being full grown on a ship off for adventure... Then becoming the captain of that ship.BAM!Cut scene's are over, you are now in control over what you do. Will you save your family? Will you pillage every ship you come across, will you rise in ranks with the different nations, will you hit on every Governor's daughter's (Did none of them have sons?)... the choices are up to you. Maybe you'll do all the things like I did, or maybe you'll only do one of them and retire from pirating.Controls:The whole game is controlled using number pad keys. You can use a mouse or  trackpad if you're playing on a laptop, but the game itself recommends you use your number pad keys.Gameplay: There's a lot of layers of complexity for Sid Meier's Pirates!. I actually had heard about the game while it was still rotting in my steam library waiting for the day I would actually download and play it.I actually had only heard good things about it, and after playing through, I can totally see why people praise this game so much!Lets cover what you'll probably spend most of your time doing in the game: raiding enemy boats, and dueling enemy captains. Once you set out on the high sea's, you'll notice the boat tends to move better depending on your direction and the direction the wind is blowing.If I didn't attack the enemy ship from above wind, normally they could escape me (unless I was attacking with a very small ship which could travel fast... but I did away with that strategy for reasons I'll explain in a few paragraphs)Again, mind you that the controls are with the number keys. so you turn your ship right and left with 4 and 6, you can change your sails with 8 and 2... and you can toggle between three weapons: 7, 1 and 3. lastly 9 changes your view, but I rarely found a reason to use it.While engaged in a duel you can choose between three attacks: 7, 4, 1. and Defending against the attacks: 8, 5, 2. and naturally you can taunt with 6. (if it sounds compliment, don't worry, it's really simple, 7 will do a "chop" attack, 4 is a thrust, 1 is a slash. 8 is a jump defense, 5 is a Parry, and 2 is a duck defense.As long as you start out on an easy difficulty the game will help you know when to defend and what to defend with... Actually I suggest you start out on an easy difficulty in general, until you learn the basics, you can always increase the difficulty whenever you destribute the spoils in a city.


After playing assassins Creed black flag, killing black beard suddenly feels very bad. 
A Screenshot of Sid Meier's Pirates!
By: Atratzu




My Sid Meier's Pirates! Story:I started out by sailing the SS Anne, I saved my Sister and plundered many a ship. The SS Anne, she was a small ship, the first ship I took over when I started the game. I saw no need to switch flag ships because I could just sail into enemy ships and take the fight to a duel between captians!This worked well for me until that fateful day... The day I met Captian Kidd on his Brig of War... I sailed directly into his ship and discovered quickly I had bitten off more then I could chew, but alas, it was far too late, I was locking blades with the Captian, but only with a crew of 20-30 so men to back me up... up against Kidd's 100-150 men.


Captain Atratzu of the SS Anne, boldly going where no pokemon trainer has gone before. 
A Screenshot of Sid Meier's Pirates!
By: Atratzu




You see, the reason having a big crew is important, is because as you lock blades with the enemy captain, both crews slowly tick down. If you cannot defeat the other captain fast enough you lose the dual, regardless of winning status.In summary, I lost the SS Anne that day and was stranded on a desert island and later picked up by another ship in my fleet....Later I was to come back and defeat Captain Kidd, and steal his ship. I renamed it to the SS Sucker Punch and beat the rest of the game with it. Saved the rest of the family, beat the "boss" evil NPC, Married and English girl from Kitts, and retired from pirating to become a Bishop. (actually I still have the save, so I could go plunder a bit more if I want a higher score and to retire as a Governor...Conclusion: I've only scratched the surface of the kind of crazy stuff on this game. Unfortunately it has a terrible case of the PlayStation2 face, and doesn't support 1920x1080 (there are probably mods which can help with that, if you look around). That's really all that I have to say negatively about the game.After upgrading my ship and getting all of the personal upgrades I was started to get bored with how easy my game had become, so next spoil distribution I kept going up in difficulties until I realized I had to chose the dueling sword, and could no longer dance with the beautiful girls because there were no helpful light up cue's in the bottom right of my screen...Basically what I'm saying is, if you think the game is too easy for you, increase the difficulty and it'll add MORE features, more strategy, and more complexity to keep you interested focused and getting more.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
Sid Meier's Pirates: Exclamation Point is an action-adventure game released in 2004, as a reboot to the original 1987 game. The player character is a pirate on the hunt for his family members who were kidnapped by a Spanish nobleman. You choose a nation to align with, be it the English, Spanish, Dutch, or French, and set sail to save your family, alongside plundering and pillaging, of course.One thing this game can tout is the amount of freedom in your choices. You can go along with the main plotline, saving your family members, or you can simply be a pirate, plundering merchant ships and pillaging cities and villages. You can also choose to avoid combat, instead being a merchant and sailing from port to port, buying and selling various goods. If you decide that's not your speed, you can ally with a nation, build up a fleet, and set out to take ships and cities from enemy factions, with a simple turn-based strategy land-assault on the cities. All of this is inbetween the sword-fighting with arrogant captains of the guard, courting and eventually wedding daughters of the cities governers, and building up your ship and her crew.The individual gameplay elements are varied, if a little bit simple. Sword fighting, for instance, is a small minigame with high, middle, and low attacks and blocks, where you try and counter your opponent and push him back. Courting the daughters of governers comes down to showing up to give gifts, participate in different events, and go to ballroom dances, which consist of a simple rhythm game. Ship battles are the most fleshed out, with direct control over your ship, three different ammo types designed to take out cannons, crew, or the ship itself. The ship can be destroyed and salvaged for goods, and the crew can be killed and the ship captured, either through one of the ammo types, or boarding and fencing with the ship's captain.The pace of the gameplay can be a turn-off; it's very slow, with travel between certain cities taking months of in-game time. The story itself isn't very focused and is more of a set up for your adventures as a pirate, with the saving of family members only really contributing to a final "point" screen. This screen is a fun little screen to me, it shows beyond the pirating part of your character's life, giving you a sense of how they do with what they've gained during the adventure itself. If you've played Mount and Blade, you'll be reminded of the retirement screen. But apart from this screen, the decisions you make don't seem to have a lot of impact. Everything from marrying someone to saving a family member is solely rewarded with points towards the end, and a cutscene.ProsThis game couldn't have more freedom if you had a bald eagle on your shoulder instead of a parrot.Sheer gameplay varietyRetirement screen adds more replayability, especially if you're the kind to want the high-score in games.Good ship to ship combatConsSimplistic storyMinigames are pretty basic, if somewhat addicting at timesLack of impact from character actionsFinal Thoughts:It's one of my favorite adventure games, easily up there with the original Legend of Zelda. If you like pirates, ships, and the freedom to play however you want, this is easily worth the buy, but if you like an indepth and focused story, you'll have to look elsewhere.Rating: 8.5/10This review was written for and is published on the  Lit Reviews [LR] curator page.

content:
Posted: May 28, 2016
												One of my favorite games of all time. I played this version of the game back when it came out in 2004 and have had nostalgic memories of it since.It's a simple enough formula, you control a ship, and can sink other ships to acquire currency resources, and more ships. You can engage enemy captains in duels, dance with governor's daughters in ports, and there's some simple mechanics revolving around turn based strategy and sneaking into enemy towns at night. There's actually quite a lot of nuance to this formula as well such as rare items you can collect to improve your abilities. Dangerous criminals to track down, treasure to find, and a decent buy low-sell high in-game economy.All of this you go through with the intent of building as much wealth and prestige for yourself as you can, because eventually, you will have to retire from your life of piracy, and when you do, you want to retire with the most land, the most titles, and the prettiest wife.The downside to the game would be it's relative simplicity I guess. Although that's also part of it's appeal. In addition, if you put in more hours than I did, you may start to find the game being quite repetitive. It's a game where you have to set your own goals, and rewards players for taking that initiative.

Posted: October 25, 2014
												Best pirate game out there. The game is a remake of classic "Pirates!" and it is worth the title. While at first I had my doubts due to cartoonish graphics the game quickly won me over. It is a charming and addictive. The game consists of mutiple minigames (sword-fighting, sneaking into a city, dancing, sieging towns.) All of them are enjoyable even though they are really simple (not necessery easy though.) Your main goal is to travel around the carribean gaining wealth and prestige by acting as a coursair for 4 countries fighting over carribean. Additionally, you have famous pirates to defeat, family to rescue from cruel Baron SomethingSomething, hidden treasure to uncover and hidden inca temples to find. All added at the end in a score based system when you decide (or a forced at certain age) to retire.It is a game I return for more every once in a while.The only real problem with the game is its focus on using numpad, which you probably don't have if you play on laptop. External numpad might work but in my case (wireless logitech) it did not. You can change the keys in the ini file, but it is a rough start as you probably won't know what to bind it to without playing the game first.Also I want a sequel. Firaxis! Get right on it.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
												Full Disclosure: Used to play this game back in its hey-day long before its Steam release. Bought it again during a previous sale just to reminisce, and its just as good as it was back then.One of the classics of Sid Meier's earlier days, brought forward to 2005, as whimsical and as rewarding as it was back then as it is now, only hampered by lack of more modern-day support features like widescreen, stability on more modern OS's, etc.+ Colorful, light-hearted portrayal of the Golden Age of Piracy, with art direction that holds up to today, 2005-era warts and all.+ Still-unique controls (using the numpad keys) make it one of the more unusual yet easiest to approach and play games to date. You can play this entire game one-handed if you wish.+ A truly open seas adventure, with only the barest of poking about the overarching story involving revenge and skullduggery. Combine this freedom with solid sea battle mechanics, sword combat, and dancing to impress the local governor's daughter and you've got something unique every run.+ In classic Sid Meier's style, many options to set player difficulty, including the option to "ante up" at each "dividing the loot" point after ever expedition with a crew.+ Yar har fiddle de dee you are a pirate~!- 2005 warts and all. No widescreen support. Lack of modern OS support (with some display issues on Win7 machines). May want to play this in a window and set your expectations of graphical fidelity properly.- Bit of a conundrum if you do not own a keyboard with a numpad.- Some would argue that the seas battle mechanics are a bit shallow, the sword combat can be difficult to get into, and the dancing is nigh impossible.- In classic Sid Meier's style, game can be haphazard in difficulty gaps between the given difficulties. - Not a ninja. Or a wizard. In space.

content:
Posted: February 21
												I remember playing this on my old Xbox Original as a kid and loving the hell out of it. Now after playing it as an adult I can still say the same. However it's not without some pretty evident flaws.The graphics are dated but that's to be expected. This game came out in 1987. Some 15 from then it would be ported to the Xbox Original where it was still widely loved. And some 20 years later it would end up on Steam. Still critically acclaimed. If you've made a game that's obviously dated but still super fun and memorable, you officially made a perfect game.The combat does take a bit of reaction and timing however once you get the trick down you'll realise how basic it is. It's still made plenty fun however by the neat little details in the battle. Sometimes you can pick up stuff from the stage and smack the opponent with it. And some of the victory scenes after each battle are very satisfying to watch. You'll laugh when the opponent get's side-swiped by a box. It's not all good news however as I've noticed there is NO POINT to using any other weapon other than the rapier. The other to weapons don't matter in a battle that requires speed. Kind of a waste sadly.Travelling the world takes some amount of patience, planning ahead and a bit of luck. You need to plan your arrivals into certain ports to keep your supplies in stock, your ship healthy and your crew satisfied. And you also need to be careful about what ships your ready to battle and what factions you want to please. It's not all about "Find the treasure, get rich, die happy." You have objectives you could do to give yourself a much better retirement. You have to find your family who were kidnapped, you have to get married to a mayor's daughter, You have to get rich, you have to really please one of the factions cause they'll give you more land which you'll eventually use to build your mansion and retire and ofcourse you've got legendary pirates to beat to become the no.1 most infamous pirate. This may sound like way to much to handle but don't worry about it, this game does allow you to tackle these things one at a time.Overall the game is fantastic. It may not be graphically pleasing but honestly if that's what you care most about then your probably a treadmill hypocrite. And no one likes hypocrites. Despite it's shortcomings it's still a fantastic game and I truly hope it get's a sequel or even a remake one day.

content:
Posted: May 14, 2016
												This is a classic example of Sid Meier's style:- Do "X".- Repeat to infinity.And it works.He's a genious at making repetitive mechanics feel super addictive. The ship battles, the progression, the exploration... it all works perfectly. I would improve the game by tweaking the sword fights, the port UI, and the dancing. But aside from that, spot on.

number of helpful: 14 of 19 people (74%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 22, 2015
												An entertaining and highly addictive pirate simulator. You won't believe how much fun it is.Most of the game is played in a top-down mode where you control a ship that can travel between ports buying and selling goods and engage in naval combat with other ships. Wind speed and direction play a role, but you can generally travel into the wind without the need for tacking. Your ship has up to three weapons which target the enemy ship's hull, crew, and sails. There are about 10ish ship upgrades, which you can buy at specific ports. You can capture extra ships and build a fleet, but you only ever control the flagship and the remaining ships just add extra crew and cargo.The rest of the game consists of a number of minigames and dialog trees.- There is a sword fighting minigame that plays like a very basic fighting game. You mainly play this against enemy captains to capture their ships.- There is a dancing minigame where you must react to a sequence of quicktime events in order to win the hearts of maidens. This is not much fun and is the worst part of this otherwise excellent game.- There is a buried treasure minigame where you walk about on land looking for buried treasure.You need to divvy up your loot with your crew periodically, at which point you lose your fleet and most of your gold and crew. You'll advance via the items you acquire and your quest progression, but much of the rest of your possessions will come and go over the course of the game.There is a plot about rescuing your kidnapped family, but this isn't really a story-driven game. Most of the actual gameplay is about capturing ships and searching for treasure.Yaar!View my other reviews here

Posted: July 6, 2015
												This game is great if you've ever wanted to sail around capturing ships, being promoted, and beating other famous pirates. The different ships are quite interesting, though I haven't yet found a giant grand frigate or anything yet, it is still quite captivating. The various quests add depth into the game, and you will find yourself dueling for the win, litterally!The only drawback to all of this that I have found is the wind. You may find yourself going quickly in one direction, and slowly in another, while your crew may be near starving, or you are badly in need of repairs, or you're out of crew members. Also, some of the fights that i've done are quite annoying, as the computer will block your strike, and counter several times in a row, effectively leading to a loss. Aside from that, this game is great, and captivating for anyone who enjoys the era of being able to plunder the royal navies, or capture ports for another country. Nice job devs!

												While I don't have many hours clocked on steam for this game, I played hundreds of hours of it a decade ago. I basically bought it in case I ever have kids, or run into people who for some friggin reason haven't played this jewel. Aspects of it haven't exactly aged well. It's incredibly male-centric, you can't play some rockin pirate queen and romance the mayors of towns or their sons - and that's a shame. The game could use some basic mod tools to open it up for a new generation - especially since a ground-up remake is unlikely. STILL - the gameplay itself is perfect. Each aspect of the game is deep enough to mesh with the other elements, and it gets surprisingly complex at the meta level. Watch a gameplay video on youtube, if it looks delightful to you - buy it - at any price. If it looks like something you wouldn't enjoy playing, give it a pass. Regardless I consider this to be THE definitive pirate game. (as of 2015)

content:
Posted: May 31, 2016
												So, I originally bought this game on sale during one of steams sales. I must say, I am very impressed by the game in a lot of different ways. Being from 2004, the game has aged well, and being a pirate on revenge in this game is still as fun from when I played on the Xbox years ago. I will go over pro's and con's of the game now:Pros:-Different countries involved in the game (English, Dutch, Spanish, and French).-Other famous pirates from history are in the game (Such as Blackbeard, Henry Morgan, Captain Kidd, etc).-Sea ship battles! (Why would this not be in a pirate game?)-Sword fighting!-Different quests (such as finding family members, finding lost cities, treasure hunting, etc).-And so many other pro's!Cons:-Daughter beauty rating (the game rates the governor's daughters off of their beauty. In my opinion, they should not be rated at all).-Crew unhappiness (this is tough to deal with in harder difficulties).-Dividing plunder (you shouldn't have to divide plunder several times throughout the game; I believe it should be a one time thing).-Getting to the city of Gran Granada (you should have to walk to get to this city. It should be accessible by water).As an overall, this game is a really great game and I highly recommend anyone who enjoys open world games and pirates to try out this game.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												Might be one of the greatest games ever made. I enjoyed it immensely as a child and I enjoy still as an adult. The game play is simple and fun. You are a pirate sailing the Caribbean. You sail, sword fight, capture ships, woo maidens, and dig up buried treasure; all while trying to locate and save your long lost family. No two game plays are alike, and I've never encountered another pirate game quite like this one... Lord knows I tried.Because I am 6, my Pirate is the notorious captain Tite Hassole. Captain Hassole is a proud duke in the Spanish armada, until it suits him. He then raided the city Margarita about 3 times and turned it into the Dutch Port of Margarita, because reasons. Tite was also a bit of a player and while he would beat a hasty retreat from any plain governor’s daughter, at least 6 times, Tite Hassole gave all the crew's money away to get a ring for a lovely lady or two. A constant issue for me is the repetitiveness of the sword fighting, and to top it off I'm not that great at it. It becomes essential to know how to sword fight well, especially in the late game, but I never got over my "smash slash really quick" routine.All in all a solid game, well worth the money and real nostalgia trip for me.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2016
												Sid Meier's Pirates! (slight spoilers) - A boy lived in a nice home with his family. As they were eating dinner, an evil man stepped in to kidnap them all, but the boy got away. He survived for years on end to eventually enter a tavern to join a crew. He had the choice of joining one of four nations: the Dutch, the English, the Spanish, and the French. This is where the player takes over and joins. Joining a particular nation only affects your starting ship as you can easily switch your allegiance to another nation or fight for no nation at all. Of course if you stay with one nation and rise through the ranks by sinking enemy ships and helping them with tasks, you will get perks such as free upgrades and repairs. Not to mention, all of your faction's towns have a governor with a daughter. They range from plain, to attractive, to beautiful. Plain and attractive women are easy to romance while beautiful women take skill. Skill in what you say? Dancing. It's actually pretty tough and I've noted that some people have ways to cheat it. You get various rewards for completing dances and can eventually marry. On your ship you can board other ships and make their ship your flagship, sink their ship, or take it to sell or keep. There are some nice ships to get such as the prized "Ship of the Line" crewed by the English. To get it you have to make the English hate you by taking their ships and assaulting their towns. Don't forget to pick up crew at a tavern, you'll need a lot to take on those bigger ships! Town Assault works differently from the rest of the game as in you take your crew to assault a town. It's kind of like a chessboard but it works quite differently. Other than towns, there are also Missions, the religious kind where monks live. They help you make friends with factions that hate you, and grow towns that you want to grow. There are also other types of settlements such as small faction towns, pirate havens. and indian villages. Other features include a top ten list of pirates, that you can kill and get good loot from their ship, as well as renown. You can also take their secret treasure by buying their maps. Remember your wife? She can give you a different map as well, a map to a secret city which will give you a literal ton of gold. The MAIN point of the game though is to rescue your whole family, so don't forget! I've enjoyed this game a lot though, so I'd give it a 7.75/10.   TLDR - It's a good game, buy it.

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												This game is actually the reason I passed the Carribean portion of my World Geography class in high school. I'm not joking. I sank a couple of hundred hours into this over a summer vacation, and I do not regret it by any means.Pirates! is the second game by Sid Meier that I played. I picked it up on a recommendation from a close friend after trying my hand at Colonization, and I feel as though I made an excellent choice with the $20 I spent on the game over a decade ago. I'd have gladly spent $20 again for this game on Steam, and the price point of only $10 is excellent.The minigames can be a bit repetative at times, and the game does not work well on netbooks. Those details aside, the game is certainly a good combination of strategy and RPG. Open worlds have always appealed to me, and this game is one of the first open-world games I played as a teenager. The quests are fairly simple, but they are still engaging and presented in such a way that a player can easily lose track of time. The graphics are quite good for a game originally released in 2004, and they've actually held up fairly well for over a decade. The soundtrack is fun and thematic, and the bright colors made--and still make--the room I play in feel like the early afternoon, even when I've played late into the middle of the night.I'll take this over Port Royale or Sea Dogs any day.

												11 years later this game still looks good enough and feels more engaging and refined than most of the titles that come out currently.The diverse gameplay allows the player to approach the game from a variety of different angles - loot other ships and ports na become the most fearsome pirate in the seven seas; hunt down notorious pirates and find their hidden treasures; trade your way to the becoming the richest governor upon retirement abusing the economy and relations of different cities; or seearch for and serve justice to the villians who did you wrong as a child and reunite with your long lost family.Chances are you will be so sucked into this game that you will end up doing all of the above time and time again until perfection is reached. number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												If there was ever a game that needed another reboot, it's this one! The game is a fantastic trip down memory lane, but after a decade, Pirates! shows its age. A combination of losing my adolescent imagination and technological advancements means that the game doesn't feel anywhere near as immersive as I once remember it feeling. 12 year old me could play this game for hours on end and feel like a Pirate on the Spanish Main - 24 year old me can only take a few hours before I find myself bored.The truth is though, the ambitious Pirates! never was immersive. The game is fun, but the charm and novelty wear off far sooner than they should. Within just a couple of hours, you'll have likely done everything the game really has to offer aside from finishing the main storyline of finding your missing family members and eliminating the other pirates. For the price, you cannot go wrong. However, the game doesn't have enough diversity in its mechanics, is not at all challenging and simply doesn't offer enough to keep you interested for dozens of hours like other Sid Meier games do.

number of helpful: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 21, 2016
												This game has a very special place in my heart. I grew up playing the NES version for hours and hours, and I imagine I'll be playing this version in much the same way. While this 'new' version is well over ten years old it's still such a wonderful and exciting game that only a pirate game of the highest caliber would be able to take it's position as Admiral of the fleet.What makes this such an incredible game is the sandbox aspect of it. The player can really pursue just about any path that pleases them. Would you like to honor your selected nation by protecting its cities from invasion, boosting its economy by plundering other nations trade goods, and making the seas a place feared for anyone that doesn't fly your flag? You can. Would you like to cast all allegiance aside and plunder the nations of their gold and goods? Go to it. Want to become a master dancer, have a wife in each corner of the map, and become the Romeo of the high seas? Your ship awaits. If you want to create a massive fleet of warships and attack towns you can do that as well. Sid Meier's Pirates is truly one of the most incredible sandbox experiences available, incredibly replayable, fun, fast, engaging, and the best pirate game available. Highest recommendations for anyone that enjoys this period of history, pirates, nautical adventures, and ballroom dancing.

content:
Posted: March 9
												Brilliant pirate game, especially on a laptop on a slow day. Nice and simple.Well, I say simple. There are a number of mini-games and mechanics that you simply have to figure out yourself, but it is quite a simple little game. Less than a gig. The cartoonish art style holds up well and doesn't look any worse when you're forced to turn off Shadows to get your frames back. I've had a few hard crashes, and alt+tabbing out causes a runtime error, but the autosave is brilliant so it's not much of a frustration.Though, the base controls require either a numpad or professional level mouse response on an on-screen interface. I found a way to rebind some controls after a couple hours hunting through forumns across the interwebs, but it's not brilliant.So it's not perfect. But I'm having a blast with it and if you're even bothering to read reviews then you will too. I'd advise waiting for a sale, it's pretty bare-bones for any more than $10.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												You take the leading role of a Pirate Captain in the 17th century Caribbean. Get fortune and fame in an attempt to seize your rightful place as one of the most revered pirate in history. Test your skills as a sea captain exploring the high seas and exotic ports in a richly detailed 3D world like for game from 2004. Overtake the enemy and seize valuable booty. Engage in plank shattering broadsides in naval battles, and in duels with opposing captains. As your reputation and skills grow, so will the size and quality of your crew, and your ability to take on larger enemy ships, raid and plunder heavily fortified ports, and locate treasures. There's a whole cast of interesting and dangerous characters to meet, mysteries to solve, exotic island to discover, and powerful alliances to forge. Like with good old England or maybe Spain, even Dutch or French. It's your free will what you do.Game is old (before Steam) so yeah, good old times when games like this were marvelous.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												Even over a decade later, the remake of Sid Meier's Pirates! is still arguably the best pirate game around. Most of the main mechanics of the game have been copied over the years as flash games and freemium mobile games, but the 3D graphics and minigames in this version make it worth a few bucks if you like that sort of game. I wouldn't pay full price for it, but at $2.50 it's a good pickup and you're sure to get a couple of hours of fun out of it.Just as a side note, this game really wants you to use a numpad. It literally BEGS you to do so. I have been playing without, and while a little clunkier it isn't awful. The game has an onscreen numpad that you can click on to achieve the same effect. However, the game does turn on NumLock without telling you, and since my laptop keyboard doesn't have a NumLock button, I was very confused when my "p" key started typing "*". I had to pull up the onscreen keyboard to turn it off. Again, not a big deal, just be aware that this happens.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												Normally I'm not big on remakes, be it movies, games, or anything else. However this is one remake that comes damn close to living up to the legend of the original. I used to spend hours playing this game on the venerable Commodore 64, then on the Amiga, and again on the old 486..First up, I will confess that I prefer the original, especially the Amiga and PC versions, but I still enjoy having a lash at this now and then. I actually bought this game when it was released, but the disc has since succumbed to bit rot, so when I saw this on sale the other day I had to buy it.The addition of extra subgames adds to the fun and there are many other small improvements such as being able to battle multiple ships at a time. The audio and the visuals suit the game well and the addition of cut scenes enhance the games charm.While it may be nostalgia that draws me to this game, I still heartily recomend it. I also recomend that people try out Pirates! Gold Plus (comes with the original 1987 game and the early 90's remake) so they can get a taste of what made the game such a classic, and why Sid Meier has long been considered a legend.4/5

content:
Posted: April 2
												Sid Meier's Pirates! blends different styles of game into a thoroughly enjoyable romp across the Caribbean. Great replay value. Seriously addictive. Not quite Minecraft levels of addictive perhaps, but at least as absorbing, and delivers more entertainment. In this open-world, you can avenge your family, woo lovely ladies, plunder cities, raid shipping; carve out an empire for your favored faction, play all factions off against one another, plunder some more... It's an old game now, and it's stylized graphics have aged well. Great soundtrack really adds to the immersive experience. Fast becoming one of my all-time favorite games.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
												Short review: BUY IT! Heaps of fun, and lots of hours of gameplay. (my play time is under-represented as I own the DVD version). Long review:Sid Meier's Pirates brings a classic game to a new generation. I remember when the original game came out, and spent many, many hours sailing the high seas - generally ending up not much higher than a pauper in the original score board at the end. Make money pirating, loot towns, rescue your family - all while under commission from the Dutch, English, French or Spanish, becoming a Duke for all 4 nationalities if you pick your targets right.This remake has a few changes from the original that in my opinion improve the gameplay, though that view is not shared by everyone.The new dance feature adds challenge to wooing the governers daughters. The previous a simple dialog choice of polite conversation, flirting or marriage offers was replaced with a complex dance scene, which increases in difficulty based on skill level and attractiveness of the woman in question. If you have any musical background, this is not too challenging as all dance moves are 8 bar sequences so you don't need to look for every hand gesture once you learn them. Those who dislike this feature however will find it a huge obstruction to gameplay, as many special items, maps, and information can be obtained this way. While you can get everything elsewhere, it takes much longer.Open-world nature of the game means endless replayability - side with different nationalities, declare piracy on everyone, play in different eras when towns are hugely fortified or not - each choice effects the overall difficulty and your final wealth and happiness. Very addictive.Recommended :)

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 22, 2015
												This game was my childhood. Although I have barely played on steam, I have spent hundreds of hours of my life in this.the game is easily one of the best pirate games around, except for maybe AC Black Flag. even getting it was a mission because it's not sold in my country. But I found a random dude in another country to buy it on my behalf. Good guy +rep.You embark on a personal mission to rescue you family from evil villain.Find the minion, find the map, find family member get more maps.Eventually you get all the map pieces and rush the fort.The sea battles are entertaining.the fencing and swordplay are fun.But the ballroom dancing, that is intense, especially on harder difficulties.It's also one of the few games to have aging as a mechanic for you but no-one else.You have a finite amount of time to win the game.Start as a teenager and when you are 70 or so, the dude who kidnapped your family, is still the same age and reallly hard to beat.Sail around, listen to cheerful piraty songs, dig up treasure and defeat famous pirates in laughably easy duels, depending on your difficulty.There are loads of different ships to capture and add to your fleet.And stingy methods to avoid paying your crew. (one of my favourite is to get most of them killed so that their share is really high and they don't get upset.)And when they mutiny agaisnt you, stealing your other ship and heading to port.There shall be no survivors.

content:
Posted: August 3, 2016
												I loved the original game on both C64 and Amiga and i'm a big fan of Sid Meier games in general eventhough i do not think he was actually involved in this remake. This version of the game has a bit of looney added to it, but it still works. Like all Sid Meier games, this game also "suffer" from the "just one more turn" effect i.e. if you are a fan, you will loose track of time playing this game. A bit pricey perhaps (currently being sold at €9.99) so i recommend getting it on sale. Keyboard and mouse are the only possible controllers and game resolutions need widescreen support (1280x960 is the highest possible resolution) but that's about the only negative things i can think of but then again, the game is from 2005 so i guess it is excused. All in all, still a good game. Get it on sale.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
												I saw this game and after a sale I picked it up.  I was a bit hesitant to play it as I had a few recent encounters where I should have left the old games in my memory as they just didn't withstand the test of time.This one, however, is still just as awesome now as it was when I first played it.I have played a lot of pirate sim games over the years, and this one, to me, is by far the best.  There is so much to do and so many ways to play - it offers a ton of replayability.  It has all the ship combat, treasure hunting, town raiding, dark alley sneaking, and ugly daughter avoiding thrills I remember and they are just as fun as ever!A very easy to learn and use interface lets you get right into it and start buckling all the swashes you can handle!  I really can't recommend the game enough, especially if it is on sale (for $2.50 USD at the time of this review).  In terms of a game you can play for a few minutes when you're bored or spend a day with those swashes we just talked about, you can count on Sid Meiers Pirates! being there for you!

content:
Posted: March 18
												Sid Meier's Pirates is just a classic and a real treat for nostalgic gamer.You like the "Pirates of the Caribbean" Movies or the TV serie "Black Sails", than this is your game.On a simple basis and good enough graphics you get to be captain of your own ship (later fleet) and cruise through the caribbean sea, getting as many coins and fame as possible.Through ship battles, sword fight and land assault you advance in ranks and fame. In taverns you get your crew, informations and sometimes maps and other gears. Charming the governor's daughter in the bigger ports is fun as well and chasing after famous pirates and take their gold just a sweet satisfaction.IMPORTANT:There are some issues with the program/software - like crashes or/and graphical problems - but through the great community there are ways to get it rolling. In my first attempt it didn't work (Windows 10) and I refunded the game, but got it again and after a short try and the help of the community and internet I got it to work.The game is just a blast and as good as the first pirates game (not "Sid Meier's Pirates", just "Pirates") I played in 2002.I can really only recommend it and wish you a great journey - Arrgh!

												This game is awesome in almost every aspect. The ship mechanics, including the speed of wind and speed based on what type of ship your using. I have spent maybe 12 hours ignoring the main quest and just pillaging gold and plunder of the spanish main. Im not saying that the main quest is bad, but its pretty repetitive most of the time like "Defeat this guy, then this guy will give you a map to your family and do it all over again". It is a lot of fun but the strong point IS NOT the main quest. I definitely play it for plundering ships, raiding towns, defeating historic pirate figures such as blackbeard, and finding lost treasures. I sometimes find bugs where even though the wind is fast the ship that the sails are in perfectly good condition still go extremely slow. The fun pirating system, plunderin, and raiding alike I overall rate this an 8/10 if the main quest were not that repetitive i wouldve rated it like a 9/10.

												Fun Game for all agesTips- Take all loot & ships you captureOnce in a town; ignore highest prices for goodssell cheapest food, goods & guns to move more freight from your hold; try to sell as much as possible;remember; typically; don't carry any more than 2-3monthsfood for your crew; as you will pick up tons more each time you take a new ship...After selling as freight (clean the merchant out wheneveryou can) next go to ship repair; repair all ships; alwayssell the smaller &/or least upgraded ships first. Upgrade any you don't sell; if the merchant offers upgrades; later whenyou sell them; you make it back; also; if something happens & you lose your main ship; you don't have to fall back to square1 with a ship that has no upgrades....Small well uupgraded ships are faster when attacking on the Seas Larger Upgraded ships are slower; but they are able tocarry more of everything; guns loot, pirates; when you capture a famous Pirate or Villian's ship;  these are bestoutfitted; some with up to 40 guns & already outfittedwith triple hammocks (carry's larger crew)...Unless you feel obligated by pride of  ancestry to chooseSpain as your national alingment; always choose another loyalty; it doesn't really matter much; you can attack ALLships if you do it right; however; there the game spawns more Spanish ships than any of the others; so there is an advantage to choosing an enemy that supplies you with plenty of targets.....

content:
Posted: November 16, 2016
												As other remakes of Sid Meier classics, like Railroads f.x., this game is a graphic rework with some new features and an attempt to get rid of tiresome features. Basic concept for these re-launches of old Sid Meier games seem to be "look hard, play easy", since it from time to time tend to lose its challenge. Compared to other games, I say this one is on the lower end as a remake, since too much has been basically "dumbed down", as for ship combat as one example. Alot of things is improved though, as the boarding combat, and some new implementations are present as well, as the possibility to win your loves heart by dancing with her at a ball. Graphics wise it's a huge improvement compared to the earlier version though, of course. All in all, as a time waste it's good enough, and there's some enjoyment in following up on the main quest of tracking down the evil spaniard Marquis Vatevahisnameis. For those who liked the original Pirates! I recommend this game.
