content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
												I honestly didn't think much of it even after seeing gameplay and the trailers and such, but I had like $3 to spare and the sale was on and I was like hey, there are so few pirate games I might as well own this one too.Man, that was the best decision I made during that sale. This is probably the best pirate game there is right now, and yes I've played♥♥♥♥♥Creed's Black Flag (And adored it) This game may be a bit old but it's aged like a fine wine. I thought it was just sailing around and raiding ships, but there's so much more. Tavern brawls, winning the hearts of governor's daughters, fighting historical pirates: It's even got frickin' stealth missions when you try to enter a town that belongs to a nation that doesn't much like you. There's even this mini RTT like mode when you raid a town which I enjoyed a lot more than I was expecting to. Worth it at $10, an absolute steal at $2.50 on a sale day.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 30
												8/10An oldie but a goodie.Easy to play but deceptively hard to master, this, in my mind, is the definitive pirate game.Not a very complicated game but highly addictive and very re-playable.The eldest child of a wealthy and prominent family from the Old World, you were celebrating with the rest of your extended family when, in the dead of night, the festivities were interrupted by a powerful and corrupt Spanish Baron. Bashing down the door, the Baron and his men storm into your family estate and, for reasons as yet unknown, takes your family hostage. You, as a child, are able to hide from the vile Baron and only you escape with your freedom. Growing-up on your own without your wealthy family's resources at your disposal, you learned to sail, swordfight, and have a natural ability to lead. But you've never forgotten the Baron or your family, still his captives. One day, though, you hear a rumor that the Baron has set sail for the New World and taken his vast fleet with him. Hoping your lost family is traveling with the fleet, you go to a local tavern and sign-up with one of the Carribbean's four super-powers.This is where the game begins. You create your character, define his name, set his profession, and choose a European nation to sign-up with. They each have their strengths and weaknesses and each will give you a different ship to start the game with. Your faction choice is not a PERMANENT one; you can change your loyalties as often as you like or even openly pirate everyone if you want.-England, whose small but well-equiped fleet has secured a number of well defended ports. Their fleet is smaller than Spain's but is the most flexible in the game; able to do everything adequately but nothing exceptionally.-France, whose strategic, but scattered, hold on the Carribbean leaves them in control of some of the most lucretive ports. Their hold on the Carribbean is tenuous when you arrive and they are threatened on all sides. With your help, though, France can grow into a power to rival Spain. Their ships are, generally, more formidable than England's but less flexible.-Holland, the smallest yet wealthiest Carribbean power. They have few cities but they are all extremely wealthy and give you access to some of the rarest goods, items and upgrades in the game. They, generally, have the weakest warships in the game and could be regarded as the hardest faction to start with but their cargo ships can hold immense ammounts of plunder and, if you're willing to invest lots of cash into upgrades, they can be turned into surprisingly formidable pirate vessels. If left alone, Holland will usually be ousted from the Carribbean fairly quickly because they hold so few ports to start with but, if you support them, the Dutch are very VERY good friends to have. If you're nice to the Dutch, they will give you the tools you need to turn nearly any ship in the game into a formidable warship capable of challenging even Spanish Galleons.-Spain, the dominant power in the Carribbean. They have more ports than England and France combined, the largest fleet and the wealthiest treasure ships. The Spanish are merciless to their enemies but can also be powerful allies. The slowest to trust, the Spanish are usually your primary target for piracy being that you'll encounter their ships pretty much anywhere on the map. At the start of the game, the Spanish will absolutely dominate all the other powers but, over time, they will become the targets of multiple wars and will slowly diminish. Eventually, near the end-game, Spain's military power will be a joke and, though they'll retain control of many cities, they will pose very little threat to the other nations by then. (Note: siding with Spain does NOT lock you out of the main storyline of pursuing the corrupt Baron as it is revealed that the Baron has gone rogue).Buy this game! It's cheap, it's fun, it's easy to play. Some of the game mechanics are contrived and get tiresome after a while (the ballroom dancing and the fencing, for instance) but the grand-strategy of the thing is worth sinking time and effort into. From managing crew morale to knowing when to divide the plunder, when to take down rival pirates and when to fight make deals and when to break them, this is a deceptively nuanced game. Beware, though! Your character is NOT immortal. The longer you play, the older he will get. If you're careful not to get arrested or marooned too often and buy medicine from taverns from time to time, you can extend your life but, eventually, you will grow old. Though it takes a while, your character will eventually enter fourties and you'll start noticing his reflexes dulling. When you enter your late fifties, you will become too old to continue your pirate career and retire from piracy. You have a limited time to accomplish as many great deeds as you can (gain promotions, mass wealth, marry a beautiful governor's daughter, rescue your family members, dig-up burried treasure, etc) so you don't have much time to rest on your laurels! Simple and fun. Just play it!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
												This is a great game. Take on the evil Spanish, greedy Dutch, slimy French, or perfidious English for fame and fortune. The progression system is truly great. Your life is split up into voyages the dength depending on how fast you can accumulate gold and how much crew you have. After each voyage you split the loot and get to increase or stay at the same difficulty, at higher difficulty you get to keep a larger share. You also get slower as you age which increases difficulty in some aspects of the game.The attention to detail is also substantial. Every faction has their own feel to them and they send out ships of their own with special missions that affect which nations are at war, the wealth and size of towns, their defence and even their allegiance. You can intercept or guard these ships to affect wether or not their mission will be successful.It also feels that there is nothing missing, and I was surprised at how many different things you could do. You could just trade, or you could fight a war, and everything in between. Sink ships or capture them, loot towns in land battles and install a governor of your liking, woo ladies in every town and even marry, search for treasure, lost cities, captured family members and love interests. There are lots of different ships with different stats, pick which suits your style best or keep a fleet so you have many options. Upgrade your ships and buy rare items to boost your own stats. Even the sailing is a mini game in itself as you try to make use of storms and wind to get where you want faster. As I said there's so much to do but nothing is hidden in some obscure corner that requires reading a manual to experience.My personal best thing with this game is that there are never any "fetch quests" so common in other rpg's, instead you are totally free to do whatever you like. Once you have captured a criminal there's never that annoying unnessecary return trip to turn him in. Raising your military rank is done by simply helping your nation in any way you want. You don't need to talk to someone first, just declare what you have done to any governor and he'll promote you accordingly.There are a couple negatives though. No ship can sail very well against the wind this means the game can slow down from its otherwise fast paced tempo. This is also not very realistic as some of the ships in the game sailed better than this. The tretirement occupation you get is also kind of breaking the immersion as even though you are a duke with thousands of acres of land and plenty of money you may get something like farmer or innkeeper just because you didn't get revenge, found all family members or got married. Otherwise a flawless game.IRemember how civilization has the mantra "just one more turn" this game although not turn based gives you the same feeling: There's always just one more thing you need to do before you can save and continue later.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												It's difficult to beat a classic, isn't it?In Sid Meier's Pirates, you play as an unnamed man who seeks vengence for his wrongfully captured family. In doing so you get the chance to captain a ship in the golden age of piracy and plunder and pillage to your heart's content! That is, if you don't care for every nation sending their best to hunt you down. But let's face it, you only need to worry about that on the higher difficulties.Most of the game is spent sailing your ship between ports, and doing whatever you feel like doing in the process, whether that be pillaging traders, hunting pirates, obtaining proffesional and eventually noble ranks with one of four nations (or all of them if that's how you swing), trading (stolen) goods, finding treasure or romancing the governor's daughter. It's all there and ready for you to sink your teeth into.Some of the more exciting features include ship-to-ship combat, swordplay, dancing at the ball, besieging cities and of course spelunking. Although the naval combat is the most prolific of these, you'll likely also find a lot of enjoyment in besting the finest pirates ever to sail in swordplay and then digging up their buried treasures just to spit at their watery graves.As far as story goes, it's alright. The backstory gives you just enough to set out after the villain (whose name I shan't attempt to spell out for the sake of my sanity) and try to rescue your remaining family. Finding your family is like a treasure hunt in itself, only with a different kind of reward at the end.All in all, this is probably one of the best games I've ever played, regardless of genre. I might be slightly biased, since I used to own a physical copy of this game before Steam even existed, and played it so much that it eventually was scratched beyond salvation. Still it's a testament to its entertainment value that anyone would play it that much. And now I've got it on my computer once again...Well, reality is overrated anyway. So long everybody! :D

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 9, 2016
												Ahoy, matey! The objective of this game is to become the most notorious pirate in the Caribbean. Together with your band of pirates you will explore the Carribean, ransacking towns, wooing the mayor's daughters, fighting notorious pirates, and attacking ships for their gold, food, and luxuries as you work your way up the pirate ranks. This game REALLY provides a strong pirate experience.I didn't enjoy Sid Meier's Civilization games because even though I liked the macro management of the civilization anytime I would order units to perform an action, I wanted to be there in the action and not just watch a sim play out. I really love games that give you a macro management but let's you take part in the lower level actions. Because of this I was skeptical that I would like this game. But I can assure you, this game is NOT like that. This definitely feels more like an adventure game with a sim as a backdrop and several mini-games thrown into the mix. The game is completely nonlinear and really doesn't have an ending as you can keep playing as long as you like. The story is weak so don't expect a strong narrative. One annoyance I had initially with the game was that there are no keybindings setup and you can't set them up in the game, so you have to manually edit the game's configuration file to the keys you want, but once that's done I found combat and dancing much easier. I highly recommend using keys for the sword fighting and dancing. Pros:+ Nonlinear gameplay+ Strong pirate theme+ Good musicCons:- No key bindings settings in-game.I highly recommend buying this game. It's worth every penny even at regular price.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
												Oh, joy! "YOR MATAL!" your pirates cheer after you capture a ship, whatever the hell that means (bless Sid Meier and his knack for inventing cutsey and timeless phonetic languages for all of his games) and your fist pumps and the gold flows. This is Pirates!, this is fun.You are Ingonito, young survivor of dastardly deeds and seeker of vengeance on the rum scented waves of the Caribbean. Your sloop, Revenge, is nimble and reasonably well gunned, and your pockets are light, your crew hungry for trouble. You have been to a town to recieve a letter of Marque from the Spaniards, the British, Dutch or French (did I miss anyone?) and now you course across the great blue expanse in search of bountious adventure.What ho! Dread Pirate Roberts has just issued from a port hidden amongst some jungled sand bars and he's telling you to watch out? Have at him!Launch flurries of cannonballs, but make sure you don't get stuck in dead air! Wheel around to dodge his projectiles while you try to maneuver your guns into position to hit his hulk - will you go for the ship's hull with cannoballs, go the masts with nunchuck-like chain-shot, or try to thin out his crew with grapeshot across the decks? No matter, this is all the prelude to the real combat - man-to-man combat with the dread captain himself on the heaving deck of his ship! Dodge blows, rain blows down upon thine enemy, chuck billhooks and drive him under a hail of swipes before eventually seeing him crash down - bloodlessly, of course - into the waves.YOR MATAL!!!!!Freaking awesome game. Lightweight, well made, endless fun, even the rinse-and-repeat gameplay doesn't get terribly old because of all the things you can do in towns, all the treature maps you can piece together, all the optional difficulty-boosts you can submit yourself to upon completion of certain waypoint objectives. Just a great, great game. And a great port, too.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												I first played Sid Meier's Pirates! on an IBM PC/25 with floppy disks (two of them, one for DOS and one for the game) with a greyscale monitor. I loved the premise, the fighting, the wooing and the general pirate behavior. It is all here, actually a couple of graphics versions are available depending on your taste. The overall story is that you were separated from your family at a young age by an evil Baron (is there really any other kind?) You take to a life of piracy and sail the Carribbean in search of loot, fame, your family, and the Baron (who is still evil). You can set your skill set to improve one skill, I strongly suggest fighting as you do a lot of it.  You can choose your nationality as Spanish (pretty easy as they sort of ruled the roost during the bulk of the time period), French, English (my choice as they start at a huge disadvantage port wise but they were at war with everyone so there are plenty of targets out there) or Dutch (also a good choice for a more difficult playthrough).  You get your letters of marque and off you go with a small ship and crew. Help your nation (or not), gain wealth and add to your fleet by taking ships (and crew). Visit ports and meet up with folks who can help or sell you map pieces to treasure or family members. Cuddle up with a barmaid or two or if you are lucky, a Govenor's daughter and find out about the goings on at port. Eventually, you will gain enough experience and learn the location of the Baron. Be prepared for a tough fight but if you prevail, you can retire with a high rank and lots of wealth.The game has several nice mechanics, your fighting skills drop with age and you may need more medicine to keep going. You also have to keep your crew happy and if you aren't getting loot on a regular basis, you may find yourself out of a job and out of luck. You can focus your efforts on your family or ignore them completely and still finish the game. The replay ability is fantastic as every game is different with lots of random elements (storms, ships you site, etc) so no two playthroughs will be the same. Your choice of nations and time period really do set different tones. You also choose how loyal you are (do you follow the Govenor's request, do you return criminals for trial, do you not attack the French when they are your ally?). By the way, the answer to the last is a resounding no.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2015
												The greatest game of all time, no question. I've bought it 6 times over a span of 10 years, and I've never regretted purchasing it. This is a game I can keep coming back to year after year, even when my adventure ends and I stop playing I'll pick the game up in a year after I've forgotten about it and I'll relive the joy of sailing around the Caribbean plundering mountains of gold and winning the hearts of lovers. The game has some amazing features that were pretty much unseen in the early-mid 2000s, whenever you get hit your health gets damaged so the game rewards the player for playing well. The higher dififculties offer a real challenge and the game progressively gets harder as you age. Ships and civilizations trade and go to war without you intefering. Entire cities can change and the game will always be different each time you play. You can play the entire game as a merchant, trading goods from city to city or you can be a pirate that sinks any ship that passes by. You can work as a privateer and assist pirates and indians to demolish the cities of your enemies. The game hits the pirate atmosphere perfectly and the music assembles in a near perfect way to provide a casual enviroment that still makes you feel like a mighty pirate. The graphics hold up suprisingly well and even though they look cartoony they're still pleasant to look at and don't get tiring.Even though the game looks simple and casual at surface level, the mechanics go very deep. There are several hidden ships that are amazing if handled correctly (Indian War Canoe) and there are several ships which are nigh impossible to get (Ship of The Line). Pirates have certain mathematical calculations that determine their wealth and were they will be. It is possible to corner Baron Raymondo by watching his behaivor and seeing where he will go, famouse pirates also plunder cities and sink other pirates by themselves. Hint: Take out Vera Cruz and the other cities in Mexico, Raymondo and Montalban will only sail toward spanish cities.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												Those who talk to me frequently about games will know of my complete OBSESSION with Pirate Games. Pirate Games as interactive audiovisual entertainment are almost, to me, an ascended form of art, and one sorely lacking in the modern industry. I have on more than one occassion been heard to utter "The perfect video game has yet to reveal itself, and in truth we know little about what it will look like when it does, save that it will categorically and undoubtedly be an Adventure RPG about Pirates"Folks, Sid Meier's Pirates! is not that game which I describe.But it comes so damn close it can smell the soap that game used in the shower this morning.This is the key from which all future great pirate games were wrought and its influence can be felt in many of the newer pirate titles. Sid Meier's Pirates! is a true masterpiece of design and implementation. Right from the off you can side with the English, French, Spanish or Dutch and get to work plundering booty and sinking trade vessels. The whole experience is knit together with some fantastically well integrated minigames: dancing with the Governor's daughter is something you feel a drive to be able to get right; you feel proud of finding a swordfighting style that's right for you, there's a sense of power and achievement from attacking and sacking ports with your pirate army. It's honestly amazing that this diverse a range of game genres (Fighting game, rythmn game, turn based strategy, real time sailing) can fit so fluidly and perfectly into one title, but they do, and it's beautiful. An absolute must buy, despite the antiquity.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2014
												Do you like pirates? Yes? Well then we have the game for ye matey!General: Sid Meier's Pirates!(I will refer to it as SMP! from now on) is a... pirate RPG... I guess? You take command of a young pirate and sail through the Caribbean in a strategy-ish POV. Your goal is to rescue your family from the clutches of gang of evil spanish dudes without dying. Now dear reader you will say well of course you shouldn't die that is quite obvious. Well it is not, in SMP! you only have a limited time to plunder until you are too old for the sea. That means be quick and find as many unique items that will prolong your life as possible.Visuals: SMP! looks due to it's sunny style and perspective quite good even for todays standarts.Audio: The sounds are not always synced with what is happening but are not bad enough for you to generally notice.Open World: The World feels incredibly alive as the differnet nations go to war, cities change their owner and missions are not as static as in other games.Gameplay: In SMP! you there are 2 kinds of missions, the ones that are directly tied to the story and side missions. Both however sometimes randomly collide as the Baron that kidnapped your family has also kidnapped your fiance.  Long story short: everything that you see in the world is something you "can do" and all of those activities are worth it, the Seas have tough spots and it all feels very alive. (Almost) Nothing that has to be triggered the old-fashioned way in a wacky sunny-pirate setting that reminds me of movies like "Mutiny on the Bounty".Story: While in itself the game offers a decent revenge story, the way the missions work make the game drag on.Basicly you hunt down those corrupt spanish guys to get information on the location of your family members(that look just like the day you lost them). However you will have to repeat this hunt multiple times to get to one of your family members. This is probably the only major problem the game has and even that is not that bad since there is more to do besides the Story missions.Final Verdict: Alive happy-go lucky Pirate awesomeness. SMP! is one of my favorite games and I can only recommend buying it especially if you like Pirates.~Captain AndGeo

content:
Posted: February 1
												First, I can't recommend this game any more, it's honestly really awesome! In search for some great pirate games (and sadly, there aren't many) I remembered this fun remake, which I personally never played the time it came out, but I remembered reading about. So my opinion is not based on nostalgia. It's no complex simulation, no it's a fun little game you  can always start over again because you have total freedom what to do and when. 2 - 3 days you might have finished one career with a playtrough, but I find myself starting over and over again a new careers, because there are so many different options, time settings and different styles to choose from. I really like the style of firaxis games, x-com is also a remake from firaxis in this style, and it's awesome. They also have this distinctive look and graphics which age very well, I think besides a low resulution compared to modern games, it still looks very good! So, sail a realistic big carribbean map, do what you want, do the main quest or don't and then start over again. For a really fun and perhaps casual game (in a good way!) it's still the best pirate game out there. A remake of this remake would be awesome. ;)

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2015
												Please bear in mind, the following is my opinion alone. You may disagree with my opinion.Sid Meier's Pirates! is an old game, but still a good one.For starters, the map is huge. There are many, many settlements which means many, many ships. More ships means more conflict, which makes for a more fun game.The duelling system is good, however after about 10 duels or so it becomes mind-numbingly repetitive, and you just end up choosing the rapier and mashing 4 all the time.I like how there is no "best" ship - sure, the massive ships have a huge hull capacity and they can therefore carry more guns and more crew, but the massive ships are very slow whereas the smaller ships which have a smaller hull capacity and have less cannons are much faster and they can dodge their way out of ramming and situations with superior ships. They can even dodge cannonballs.Because logic.The graphics aren't very good, but give the devs a break, it was made in 2004.There are some cons, like with every game. There is a bug where when you go back onto your ship (when you have gone onto land) with the spyglass still in use, your ship moves ridiculously slowly and the spyglass is still there, meaning you have to go through the incredibly tedious process of turning around at 0.000000001 knots and landing again, then putting away the spyglass and getting back on the ship.And there is very little variation in the gameplay so after one or two playthroughs it becomes extraordinarily boring.However, while it still lasts, this game is worth buying. It's bad, but it's also very good.RATINGSGraphics - 4/10Gameplay - 6.5/10Story Originality - 1/10The Actual Story - 2/10Value for Money - 5/10Replayability - 4/10Length - Can't be rated, there isn't a definite point where the game ends, but you get bored after about 10 hours (counts as 6/10)Extra Special Feature - Balanced ships and huge mapMy Final Rating:6.8/10GoodMean Average rounded to 3 dp:4.071/10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20, 2016
												I was actually extremely surprised by how good this game was. I picked it up during a weekend sale based on reviews by some of the other steam users. I couldn't believe that so many people enjoyed a game that's essentially for kids.Sid Meier's Pirates! puts you in the role of a buccaneer who had his family kidnapped by your traditional "evil noble". You sign up with one of four major empires--England, France, Spain or Norway--and sink ships, conquer cities, raid caravans and fight off rogue pirates. As a naval leader, you rise in rank from a simple privateer all the way up to the commander of the royal navy. You outfit all of the ships in your fleet and engage in sea battles for ultimate supremacy of the Caribbeans.Sid Meier's Pirates has a surprising amount of depth for such a simplistic game. It has political elements, economics, resource management, sword duelling and...dancing. Yes. There is ballroom dancing in Sid Meier's Pirates. Let that sink in for a moment.I think it has something to offer for everyone. However, there are some downfalls. The difficulty quickly dies down as you amass larger, more well-armed ships. The various game aspects become repetitive after the 8 or 9 hour mark, and the campaign--which is quite short--can be completed with almost no difficulty, especially after acquiring the Duke's ship. There is a lot to do, but it can be done in a short amount of time. I finished the game and most of the quests in about 3.5 hours. So, while it is a good game, it doesn't exceed its financial value in any way. You get what you pay for, plus a little extra.PROS++ Expansive map with a lot to do.++ Amazing ship battles; very engaging and fun!++ Many different activities and side quests to complete apart from the campaign.++ SWORD DUELLING! CONS-- Limited story elements.-- Main campaign is shallow and easy to complete.-- Not much replayability once the quests are done.-- The ballroom dancing. Blech. As a guy, that was cringeworthy.Overall, the game is worth about a 7.5/10. Definitely a good game and worth the money.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2011
												Pirates! is a really classic game for me - though I admit it could be part of its appeal to me was that it was so far ahead of its time when it came out. Free roaming, sailing with different handling depending on the size of the ship, a map based on the real world, two types of battle, leadership, piracy and privateering for political gain, marrying women, hunting treasure, searching for long-long relatives and trying to quell your crew from mutiny... all in a game from the mid-1980s. The only thing that even nearly matched it in terms of depth was Elite.It's received updates, and updates, and updates, and... it's still the same game, at the core.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2014
												9/10This game is one of my favourite Sandbox Games that i've played in the last 2 years. Your family is imprisoned by an evil Spaniard, the Marquis Montalban! By this time, you are a young boy, who manages to escape imprisonment. 18 years later, you are a fully grown man, who decides to sign up on a ship (of your choosing). You decide whether to join crew with the Spanish, the Dutch, the French, or the English. Either way, you later mutiny against your captain with nearly the rest of the crew. After defeating the captain, the crew elects you captain. You are then allowed to do whatever you wish. Be that fighting for a certain nationality, being a Pirate and attacking everything in sight, raiding towns, attacking merchant ships, trying to rescue your long lost family, defeating the 9 best pirates in the game (Blackbeard, Henry Morgan, Stede Bonnet ETC) or just doing whatever you feel like doing.The game may take a bit of time to get adjusted to, but in the end, the amount of enjoyment and fun you recieve from playing this is just amasing! So overal, I HIGHLY recommend getting this game, especially when its on special sale thing (like the Steam Summer Sale ETC).

content:
Posted: April 8, 2014
												I got hooked on the Sid Meier's Pirates! series years ago and I was glad I was able to find this version on PC.Aesthetically the game isn't what most people are used to seeing these days but it is an older game and is very detailed in it's artwork. The period-centric music and sounds are great and while there is no actual dialouge, the gibberish word-sounding noises characters make can be hillarious in the right scenarios. The mechanics on the PC version work a little different so if you're used to the XBOX version like I was be prepared to retrain your and when you start dancing with the governer's daughter.It is a pirate game so you have plenty of booty and plunder to acquire as well as hidden treasures and lost cities and both sea battles and sword fight. Aside from the standard fighting and looting you find in most pirate games, Pirates! offers up trade goods to sell, daughters to be wooed and married to, and more importantly keeping your crew's morale high so you can stay at sea longer.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 12, 2014
												Game of the year, every year. This game was fantastic upon it's rerelease in 2005, and it has yet to be matched. The quintessential pirate game, with the bare minimum of missing features and an exceptional amount of depth.Want to sail around and plunder Spanish Treasure ships? Sure.Want to find take down the 9 most notorious pirates in the Carib? Go for it.Want to find treasure map fragments and search around distant jungles to find them? There are hundreds.Strategy Minigame? Check. Stealth Minigame? Check. Dancing Minigame? You bet your♥♥♥♥♥ Duelling mingame? Naturally.This game has everything, all fine tuned and polished, not a single bug to be found. The style is timeless, casual and silly but not lacking. If you thought that AC:Black Flag had a good pirate thing going, then you need to pick this up and be blown away.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2011
												Oh boy. Now this, this is one of my favorite games of all time. A rare example of where simple =/= equal fun. It's a rare example (if not the only) of where you can literally just sail around and do whatever the hell you want right off the bat, having oodles of fun whilst making oodles of gold. Hardcore to easy, ship combat is handled by steering the boat while giving orders to fire. There is a wide variety of boat 'models' and upgrades to temper how this handles, and there are multiple cannonball types. Dancing, and fencing are handled in a DDR fashion with the numpad, with 8 as up and so on. It works suprisingly well and can be rewarding to see your rougish character sweep the danish noblewomen off their dainty feet.If you aren't looking for an overly complex story and just want to hop in and have some short, but nonetheless addicting fun. this is one of my favorite games, and in my opinion up there with civilization as one of Sid Meier's great contributions to gaming.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												8/10For however long I have been playing this game, I can give a few things that I think would be helpful to someone debating on buying this. I bought this for like $2.50 when a sale was going on. The game is DEFINITLY worth at least $10.00 though...Goods:-Open world partly on ship, very little on land, some forced minigame, easy UI for movement.-Fun missions.-You get the sense of accomplishment for doing practically anything but losing.-Treasure maps are an entertaining game dynamic.-Take over literally ANY ship and use it as your own.-Raiding towns is fun.-Player items actually make a difference in a variety of aspects of the game.Neutrals:-Gameplay dynamics and reward increments revolve around difficulty.-Dancing can get more difficult as difficulties progress, and having to press 1 of 8 options in the fraction of a second based off of your partner's gestures is not very simple.-Crew is hard to keep happy unless all you do is what pirates would do even though the game gives you the ability to be 'good'.-Graphics match their time.-Winds heavily effect movement around the map.-You only retain your flagship when you give the crew members their cut.-Some ships will not engage in ship to ship warfare and instead will follow windward right into you and force you into a cinematic minigame.-Only about 6-8 ship upgrades.Bads:-Sometimes can be very repetitive.-Sailing down certain inlets can cause the game to continually ask you if you would like to anchor.-The Spanish own the entire south half of the Caribbean. (Not really as bad since it is pretty historically accurate. more difficult attacking vessels without upsetting the Spanish).-When escorting another ship, another WILL spawn and attack you at some point on the voyage.

												This is probably my second favorite Sid Meier's game (first would be one of the Civ games)! It's incredibly fun! A little goofy but genuinely piratey! Oh and if anybody has difficulty with the dance sections, just wait to press the button until your partner nods her head. If you do it before you might trip.Buy it! It's great!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 17, 2014
												I've always wanted a good pirate game, where you can recruit and manage your crew, customize your ship, terrorize the seas, and search for buried treasure.  Though this game only includes some of those features, it manages to be the best pirate game available (even better than AC: Black Flag in terms of a pure pirate experience.)  Though the visuals are simple, and some of the minigames get old quickly, this game kept me hooked for a long time.  Hopefully in the near future, we can get an updated version of this game, or another attempt at a great pirating experience that doesn't include an Animus.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
												Pirates is a good game. That is if we look at where it is in comparison with current games. In comparison to the games that were around when this was released it was superb.I am running it on win 8.1 with not problems whatsoever; OK, the graphics are dated, but not unplayably so; the sound is not the best around now, but again this is not a problem.I loved the original game and this rework is just as good. There is dancing, which I was always crap at and I expect I will still be crap at; the fighting onboard ship takes a bit of getting used to; I expect that will come back to me, (Already lost and slung in a French prison, just because I attacked a French ship and got too close and started a boarding action when I really should have stayed away a bit longer!) The naval battle mechanics are pretty good, not Black Flag but this is a game that is 9 years old!So, yes I do recommend it, I have had no problems getting it to run on 8.1, and it is a real reminder of the good old days! I got it in the winter sale, or perhaps that should be SAIL maybe? :-) and I have already abandoned one career in less than an hour. Not to self; always keep enough cash with you so when you escape from prison you can afford to repair your ship. (Attacking when your ship is damaged is not worth it, your victim can sail away!

As a guy, that was cringeworthy.Overall, the game is worth about a 7.5/10. Definitely a good game and worth the money.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2011
												Pirates! is a really classic game for me - though I admit it could be part of its appeal to me was that it was so far ahead of its time when it came out. Free roaming, sailing with different handling depending on the size of the ship, a map based on the real world, two types of battle, leadership, piracy and privateering for political gain, marrying women, hunting treasure, searching for long-long relatives and trying to quell your crew from mutiny... all in a game from the mid-1980s. The only thing that even nearly matched it in terms of depth was Elite.It's received updates, and updates, and updates, and... it's still the same game, at the core.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20, 2016
												I was actually extremely surprised by how good this game was. I picked it up during a weekend sale based on reviews by some of the other steam users. I couldn't believe that so many people enjoyed a game that's essentially for kids.Sid Meier's Pirates! puts you in the role of a buccaneer who had his family kidnapped by your traditional "evil noble". You sign up with one of four major empires--England, France, Spain or Norway--and sink ships, conquer cities, raid caravans and fight off rogue pirates. As a naval leader, you rise in rank from a simple privateer all the way up to the commander of the royal navy. You outfit all of the ships in your fleet and engage in sea battles for ultimate supremacy of the Caribbeans.Sid Meier's Pirates has a surprising amount of depth for such a simplistic game. It has political elements, economics, resource management, sword duelling and...dancing. Yes. There is ballroom dancing in Sid Meier's Pirates. Let that sink in for a moment.I think it has something to offer for everyone. However, there are some downfalls. The difficulty quickly dies down as you amass larger, more well-armed ships. The various game aspects become repetitive after the 8 or 9 hour mark, and the campaign--which is quite short--can be completed with almost no difficulty, especially after acquiring the Duke's ship. There is a lot to do, but it can be done in a short amount of time. I finished the game and most of the quests in about 3.5 hours. So, while it is a good game, it doesn't exceed its financial value in any way. You get what you pay for, plus a little extra.PROS++ Expansive map with a lot to do.++ Amazing ship battles; very engaging and fun!++ Many different activities and side quests to complete apart from the campaign.++ SWORD DUELLING! CONS-- Limited story elements.-- Main campaign is shallow and easy to complete.-- Not much replayability once the quests are done.-- The ballroom dancing. Blech. As a guy, that was cringeworthy.Overall, the game is worth about a 7.5/10. Definitely a good game and worth the money.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												I love this game! I have for over 20 years. Probably my favorite game in the history of video games and I wouldn't be alone in that thought. This is a remake, of a remake, of a remake. All of them are good, but I like the 1987 version for NES the best. There are minor changes in this version that I do not like or enjoy as well as the older versions. (Cartoonish graphic style, silly voice sounds, and ballroom dancing) being the main drawbacks. However it's still a great game. I wonder if it's not time for another remake of this timeless classic? With modern realistic looking graphics, expanded trading system, professional voice acting, and a darker more sinister plot and overall feel. THAT would make it AWESOME! I can only hope.

												Really fun game if you just want to play a game where you can kick back and relax.  The controls however are wierd at first, but you'll get used to it later as you play.Ships you want to aim for as a beginner are the ones listed belowBrigsFrigatesSloopsShips you want to aim for as an expierenced playerLarge Frigate(Can carry a large crew, make sure you have a big crew to board them)Ship of the Line/Man-O-War(Only appears on higher difficulties when you cause a lot of trouble with trade routes and such, deadly firepower, avoid being hit as these deal devastating amount of damage if you do not have an armor upgrade) -If you are feeling confident on taking them on, give it a go, you'd be a fool to sink that beast.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												I brought my thirst and swag into a local tavern off an island I was sailing by, we proceeded to drink and dice, and having a luck roll of 77 when I was born, the gambling addict was soon out of money. He proceeded to bring me into a back room and show me this girl he had found as a stow away. Double or nothing he says for the girl as collateral, Wanting to bang out as many chicks as possible before the redcoats end my reign of terror I of course accept and walk away with a new wench. She proceeds to tell me she is looking for her husband, a naval officer who went missing, and If i was a decent man I'd help her. I proceeded to shut her down and make her train my sailors to bring morale up. A year goes by and I'm at another tavern; a man comes up to me and tells me that I own his wife and hes been looking for her all this time, would I part with her out of a sense of lost romance and love? I of course decline because this isnt a charity, he offers 10,000 gold, I accept. Its 4am and I log off, when I retern my coffers are filled with 1,000,000,000 Gold.  I proceeded to throw volley after volley of conscripted men into the meat grinder of local forts until I owned the worlds best fleet. Needless to say the game was ruined after that, but I was the best pirate in the land.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												FIXED!: I still say "buyers beware", but I have found a reliable, and good fix for the problems I have been having. I am hoping this fix is good for anyone else who was having the same issue. It is a game made before Windows Vist, 7, and 8, and thus was not optimized for play on those versions. I hope these solutions work for you, so that you can seemlessly enjoy this classic.Fixes random crashes: http://www.pcgamer.com/2014/07/31/pixel-boost-sid-meiers-pirates/?ns_campaign=article-feed&ns_mchannel=ref&ns_source=steam&ns_linkname=0&ns_fee=0Fixes "steam not found" error: http://forums.steampowered.com/forums/showpost.php?p=26798077&postcount=13----------I love this game. I have spent hours and hours playing this before, on Xbox, as well as Windows. However, I cannot play this version for more than 15 minutes before it crashes. It is really annoying. There are some compatibility issues with modern versions of Windows that cause this, and has never been patched. I recomend this game if you are playing on a Windows XP machine. However, if you are on Vista or later, especially 64 bit, just beware.

content:
Posted: March 9
												Looking for someone to tell me I'm wrong with the following statement.  This game is perfect . . . except for:1. Ship speed is everything for winning this game on the hardest setting, thus making all the dif ships you can get moot; expecially trying to sail around slowly with a whole fleet--something you'd never do trying to win the hardest dif.2. The game provides several avenues for making money, but just basic capture/sell is so much faster/effective than anything else; which also makes the rest moot.3. The sneak-in-to-town mini-game is way to high risk vs. reward, so again in a game you're trying to win, you'd never do this . . . unlase you "save-scum"Recap: the designers put in multiple paths to victory in this game (a must for any "good" game), but once you discover the "correct" path, it is so overwhelmingly the "correct" path that even if you force yourself to try something different all you can think is this is stupid and can do task X in 1/2 the time (time - the greatest commodity in the game) by doing it the "best" way.  Again, please someone tell me I'm wrong.

Posted: January 27, 2016
												I really had my reservations about this game. It looked a little dated, and not much content. I do like ships and pirates and trading and after I got the game in a humble bundle i decided id give it a go. This game is wonderful. You start out as an apprentice level sailor with the que's flashing during fights and dances so you dont fail. Then journeyman comes around and the que's are gone and you have to see the movement of the person your fighting or dancing with to have an idea of what your defence/dance move should be.At first i thought it was dumb that you could only battle one ship, but that ship you have direct control over and it would be difficult to control more, and relying on AI to fight with you brings in risks of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ decisions. Over all, this game is really worth it. i would have paid the 10 bucks in full if i knew what i was getting into

content:
Posted: December 9, 2016
												Should we accept a classic as a classic after the era it became a classic in stops being classic? This is the classic question that I would love to finally classify and I shall provide a vintage standard and time-honoured solution to this problem. Pirates, classically, are known as the typical scurge of the usual seven seas we are all familiar with. However, this classification is typically unjust. Sid Meier's classic experience, Pirates! focuses on the most representative of all classical periods of piracy, namely the Golden Age in the Caribbean of pre 1730 vintage. I want to point out that typically, a classic pirate crew of this day would not be a simble group of your usual scoundrels, but in fact much closer to the democratic nature of classical liberals. While I don't believe that the classic game Sid Meier's Pirates! represents this class of pirates in a standard manner, it does make a good attempt at showing how Piracy was a reasonable and standard career choice in this era.Now for the typical pros and cons;+Classic arcade combat+Classic lost family story line+Classic famous pirates (collect the skulls of all 9)+Classic ship designs +Classic game-Classic repetitive gameplay-Classic ugly charachter models-Classic scurvyOverall, this game is a classic that still stands the test of time. A true classic for video games!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2014
												Sid Meier has made many games with clever tactical depth, but is not so swollen with rules, so that anybody can jump right in. Pirates! continues the tradition by being a game chock full of strategy, but is highly accessible.The game is a sandbox. You can go anywhere, and do anything, within the Spanish Main. Generally, you plunder ships or towns, and get promoted by friendly nations. There are plenty of other things to do, too.Tasks you perform have an associated action oriented mini-game. You'll be ship-to-ship battling and swordfighting a lot. I like most of these games, though your mileage may vary. Many people have mixed feelings about them.As far as management goes, the game cuts out micro-managing. The action just keeps flowing. The typical mundane busy work of hard-core strategy games is kindly removed here, in order to get to the good bits. There are plenty of strategic decisions to be made, but you get to think in a sense of what you WANT to do, not what you HAVE to do.Certain things are a little tricky to get used to. Sailing East is much harder than sailing West. Your crew slowly becomes restless over time, forcing you to pay them off and take a few months vacation before going back to sailing.After you get to the ripe old age of about 35, your health starts to decline, and you might have to retire before too long. This takes you to an amusing detailed report on your post-pirate life. Hopefully you are a Governor instead of a Pauper!The graphics and sound are cartoony. Everything looks like it's from a Disney/Pixar movie, and the voice acting is done in jibberish, like in The Sims. Subtitles are in English, though. The cartoony feel is not bad, but is sometimes just a little TOO campy.The controls are a bit strange. While you can use a mouse, you're better off doing the mini-games using the numpad. It's a little awkward at first, but you get used to it fairly soon.Pirates! is one of my all time favorite games. Two thumbs and a wooden peg-leg up!

content:
Posted: September 22, 2013
												Pirates! is a game I played quite a bit in college, and playing it again now, it holds up surprisingly well. You play as a Caribbean pirate in a small ship, and you can use it to build up a huge fleet, earn a fortune, find lost cities of gold, and do tons of other things. More than anything else, Pirates! is a sandbox game. It will suggest things to do, but you're free to set your own goals.When you're not sailing, most of the Pirates! gameplay is in the form of mini-games. You'll become very familiar with Fencing... your sword will solve many problems. But you can also participate in naval combat, dance, siege towns, sneak into hostile towns, or hune around the wilderness for treasure. Most of them are short, simple, skill-based games that are incredibly easy on low difficulties, but can get near impossible on the higher ones.The graphics were good for their time, and they've held up better than I expected. The music is nice, but there's not enough of it. The game usually controls well enough.I got this game when it went on sale, and I've been having a lot of fun with it again. I'd wait for a sale to get Pirates!, but when it does, this is a game worth getting.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												Pirates! is the all the swashbuckling fun a person could want from a pirate-themed video game without being too restrictive. It lays out a basic backstory with optional follow-through, but otherwises allows the player to run wild in the 17th Century Caribbean. At times, however, the game can be a little too hands off in terms of direction (explanation of game and world mechanics and parts of the "storyline"). The controls can a little confusing at first, and I would really recommend a number pad if using a laptop but a mouse is a good alternative also (I've used both and found that while the mouse is more convenient a number pad makes the game much easier to play). Overall, this game is easy to get a hang of quickly and you'll have a fantastic time pirating your way across the high seas.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												Score: 10/10Although Sid Meier's Pirates! is a very old game, it gives the player an unrivaled pirate experience. You are free to make your choices and shape the world in any way you see fit, and that is what I call a true RPG. Which brings us to what I believe is the strongest point of this game, the hability to provide an amazing interaction with the game world, even if you don't realized as you do, as every action brings a reaction somewhere. If you save the merchant ship from the pirates, your allies may prosper, but that very pirate ship that you sunk will be a hard hit in the pirate community. Or, if you are to become the most fiered pirate of the seas, you might find that your pillage is bringing cities to decline.The other mechanics in the game do not present any remarkable point, but been able to have old school ship fight is quite amusing, as well as deciding your batles by your favorite method of combat (ship/sword fight). The graphics and sound are alright and there is no plot, you make your own history.This game deserves a 10 for the great interaction mechanic it carries even being decades old! Definitely a gap to be yet filled.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												Sid Meier's Pirates! is a surprisingly fun and deep simulation of being a ship captain in the Caribbean during the glory days of piracy. You're not limited to being a pirate. Although the game doesn't explicitly say so, the simulation of the four major powers and two minor powers operating in the Caribbean is quite complex. There's a real war going on, and all of it happens by sea. Although invasions happen over land, troops don't get into position to invade unless they're transported by ship. Many troops don't get paid and people don't get fed unless their wages and food arrive by sea. The economy is primarily based on sea trade, and blockades occur. Warships must be built and sailed where they're needed. And governors and other important people move around by ship.All this means that there's a rich environment for you to play in, and many possibilities for how you want to play. You can, of course, be a pirate and loot the treasure ships of all the wealthy nations. You can serve a nation as a legitimate but independent privateer. You can pretend to be part of a nation's navy and go to war on its behalf, attacking targets of military importance and earning the appreciation of the nation even if you don't get much money out of it. You can even take part in land-based invasions and try to conquer cities, either for the benefit of a nation - territory really changes hands in this game - or just to loot and pillage. Or you can be a peaceful trader. The lesser powers, pirates and Indians (i.e. Native Americans), have their own agendas which enrich the environment further.Besides the sandbox gameplay, you have several concrete goals: rescue your family, acquire wealth and fame, woo beautiful women, find hidden treasure and lost cities, bring villains to justice, and defeat the top pirates in the Caribbean. There are also minor quests that allow you to act as a law enforcer (or turn a blind eye to crime in exchange for bribes, if you wish), and mini-games such as breaking into enemy towns, dancing (which is quite fun), and both real-time combat at sea and turn-based combat on land.There's a lot to do, and for the most part it's all well-designed. There are five difficulty levels, allowing the game to be enjoyable for all players, and several eras you can start in and skills you can specialize in, which increase replay value. The game's main shortcoming is that it's too easy, because it helpfully auto-saves before anything bad happens, allowing you to simply reload your game and retry. This diminishes the importance of many gameplay elements, such as breaking out of jail, upgrading your character, and maintaining multiple ships in your fleet, and leads to excessive risk-taking while dampening the thrill of success. The game really needs an Iron Man mode. (Thankfully, a mod to add one exists.)Another potential problem for some players is that the game doesn't have much of a tutorial, but the manual is good and worth reading.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
												When I picked this game up, I had been having this urge to play a pirate game. Something open world, where I could choose my own path, but still be a pirate. I wanted the game to be about more than just continual swordfights. As I looked over the community reviews on various "pirate" games, there didn't seem to be a lot out there that offered open world freedom.Sid Meier's Pirates! offer you that freedom. You can determine the size of your crew, the routes you travel, even who you fight: you are offered the chance to be a privateer for any of 4 different countries (Don't worry, you don't have to serve any allegiance). You also get to decide if you will be the pirate that raids ships and pillage towns for a living, or more of a merchant/pirate that buys and sells goods as well. There is a main questline of finding your long lost family and getting revenge against those responsible, but it doesn't get in the way of any other path you choose.Now, Sid Meier's Pirates! isn't perfect. Some of the minigames get very VERY tedious the ninth or tenth time you do them (dancing with the governor's daughter). But all around, this is a very fun game. And for it's price, this game was definitely worth it, especially for those of you looking to scratch that Pirate itch.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 25, 2014
												Sid Meier's Pirates is one of his best games, alongside Civilization 4 and Civ 5. In this game you can experience the exciting world of the 18th century Caribbean, filled with notorious pirates like Blackbeard, buried treasure, and devastating storms to blow you off course. There are two basic ways you can play the game: You can plunder every single penny from every single person, or you can obey every law there is, and befriend the governor of every town and city on the map. And, of course, you can be somewhere in between. This game has one drawback I will mention: you must have a number pad on your keyboard to play it. Almost everything from sailing your ship to the swordfighting minigames requires the number pad. Aside from that limitation, it is a great game. Not too difficult, but not too easy. I recommend that you purchase this game and try it out for yourself. If you like Sid Meier's other games and you like pirates, you'll like this.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2011
												I really wanted this game and after a year or two of waiting I bought it.I went through and fully completed the campaign in about twenty to twenty-five hours, so this can last you awhile.There is swashbuckling and ship battles to be had!You can own and command a fleet of ships ranging from a Canoe to a fearsome "Ship Of The Line".When you divide the plunder you can choose to stay at your current naval rank/ game difficulty or get a promotion and slightly increase the game's difficulty. You can also look for buried treasure by purchasing or finding a treasure map.You can attack any ship you see even ones you're supposed to be escorting.You can attack or invade any port or town, to do this,Attack a town with your ship's cannons to kill most of it's men, then invade by land to capture or pillage the town.The graphics are good, music is decent and the dialogue is good aswell.I rate this game, Eight War Canoes Out Of Ten.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12, 2014
												Been wanting a fun pirate game for a while, and since AC Black Flag just didn't do it for me I tried this out.  To my surprise this game is awesome.  Can easily put many hours into it and is simple yet deep and fun.  Totally sandbox, and you can plunder to your hearts desire.  It's definitely a Sid Meier's kinda game, and its old so the graphics and RPG elements are a little dated.  But its definitely worth the small price tag and I would ABSOLUTELY recommend if it was on a steam sale.  However, I truly wish a decent pirate RPG would come out with: leveling, weapons, ship upgrades, custom crew members, sea/land battles, and a good story; as this game sadly is not that.  And that game would most definitely sell.All in all, simple, fun, addictive.  Good purchase.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
												Eh, Pirates still is a playable and fun game after all these years, but the many quirks get old quickly. There are a handful of activities to acomplish with a handful of minigames that involvethe numpad, mostly. You can defeat and plunder other ships, sword fight, buy and sell goods, explore the map, track down other notorious individuals, dance with governor's daughters, escort various other ships from town to town, build a skilled crew and search for buried treasure. That sounds like a ton of different things, but it gets repetitive quickly. I like that the game allows you to increase the difficulty level as you deserve it, but when I stopped playing, I realized I  had a bad understanding of the sword fighting mini-game, and has simply bumbled through it at earlier difficulties, and I was having to reload to deal with every other battle, which got really tiring really quickly. I never could find my sister, which was the goal of the game. Maybe I'll reappoach the game with a new character and see if I can be a bit more efficient.

content:
Posted: October 11, 2013
												I bought this game with low expectations but, with it being on sale and all, I figured "why not"  - looking to scratch an itch for boarding vessels and some fun swordplay, I went for it.  Whilst not bowled over entirely, this game IS very addictive, and I played it for several long, intensive sessions; certainly getting good value for money in the process.What we have here is more a collection of minigames than anything else; hotkey-based swordplay and dancing, a very detailed sailing simulator (albeit an easy one), and some grid-based TBS thrown in for good measure if you decide to take your crew ashore to plunder a town.A good game, but with limited replayabiility as you tend to find the "optimum" build very quickly.  I'd pay £5 for this game.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2014
												I owned the game for xbox and picked it up with the Sid Meier's Humble bundle.  I am very happy to have a working copy again.  I really liked the xbox version, but the PC version is way more indepth in some areas, mainly heading to shore when running aground. My only gripe is that I feel it is a little repetitive at times.  A bit outdated, but what do you expect from a game from 2005.What did surprise me was the difficulty I had playing on my wife's laptop.  I connected a keyboard for the number pad but found that even moderate graphics settings were taxing on the computer.  It is a 3-4 year old computer with only a 3 core Phenom in it, but considering the game's age I feel like it should have handled the whole game with ease.  I play on my desktop usually so it's not an issue, just surprising.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2014
												Sid Meier's Pirates another great game from a great game maker. Your family is taken for ransom, you grow to be a teenager and you are ready to set sail to try to free your enslaved family from the evil Colonel.Or you can say SCREW THAT, IMA GO PLUNDER SOME SHIPS!!! You are free to do so :)This is a pirate-sandbox game. Similar to the newly released Pirate Game, Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag. You can follow the storyline and set free your enslaved family, or you could go out to sea and plunder, get yourself married to a governer's daughter, gather the ships of Blackbeard, Black Bart, and Captain Morgan, upgrade them to their highest, THEN go out and rescue them. This is what I like about Sid Meier's games, its got good sandbox engine to it. The Carribean is HUGE, you could sail for hours and maybe not even get 100% of the content done.The Melee combat is fluid, but a little TOO easy. Just counter when the button flashes, then attack. The ship combat is fun as well, although its very trivial if compared to Black Flag. If you wish to go save your family and THEN take down famous pirates, feel free to do so! It is important to note that you should not split your loot until you feel you are ready to do so, because you will lose some ships and loot and you need all the loot you can get since upgrades and items are expensive, but it makes it so money HAS a use at least. Unlike Black Flag, this game requires you make an effort to keep your ship in good condition and your crew happy, if your crew gets unhappy, they will abandon you. You dont want that.As I said, the Carribean is huge, but honestly in this game, Its kind of TOO big. Black Flag has a function where you can initiate Travel Speed and get where you need to go faster. This game only has half and full sails, and even then, if you dont follow the wind direction, your not gonna get anywhere in the next 5-10 minutes. It should also be worth mentioning that you do NOT have any sort of waypoint system in this game. You have to navigate your way around, which can be a bit difficult, but if your patient, you'll start getting it.So, is this game good? Yes! This is for you if you absolutely love the Golden Age of Piracy and want to experience it in a way.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
												This game is like 5 games in one: sailing, real time ship battles, fencing, turn based strategy, dancing (Rhythm game), and more. Stick with me here though: what makes classic nintendo games great, is that they are simple enough for a newbie to pick up and enjoy but also evolving with enough depth to grasp a hardcore gamer. THIS IS THAT TYPE OF GAME and what makes Pirates! so great as well. Start out as an apprentice -each time your crew is unhappy, divide the plunder to start refresh and jump to the next diffculty level. The game really progresses from each tier of diffculty nicely til your at the most difficult level and you are like wow, how did this game get to this point, it was so easy at first. The graphics still hold up too! Play this now! Trust me, there is something for everyone in this game.

content:
Posted: August 5, 2013
												My second favorite pirate game of all time.  Favorite being Uncharted Waters: New Horizons on the SNES.  This game is entirely based in the Carribean.  Starting the game up you choose what type of pirate you are going to be by picking a skill.  After that you pick your nationality.  You can choose between Spanish, English, French, and Dutch.  The Spanish seem to have the most ports and cities so I'd consider them the easiest to start with.  You work your way up the pirate ranks by finding buried treasure, defeating notorious pirates like Blackbeard, and trading goods between ports.  It's a great game and worth the price in my opinion.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 16, 2012
												Sid Meier's Pirates! is a 2005 remake of the original game he made back in the 1980s. This time, you have better graphics, more advanced swordfighting sequences and more options for everything. You start the game off by leading a mutiny on a merchant vessel. From there on, you can decide whether you want to avenge your family by defeating the Marquis de Montalban, defeating all the major pirate captains in the Spanish Main, accumulate vast amounts of wealth through trade, marry a governor's daughter whether she be sexy or ugly, or if you want to attack merchant ships, plunder seaports and instigate a brand new war. The choice is yours! My only complaint is that you can't customize your character: although he does age, you always have to be the Orlando Bloom type of character. Beyond that, this game is every sandbox adventure you ever dreamed of.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 17, 2014
												For a game that's over ten years old, Pirates is easily the best game I've played in a long time.  It brings a romanticized view of a century of piracy to gaming, yet avoids Treasure Island clichés like parrots and peg legs.  You'll find a lot of light comedy in the presentation of the game, too!  However, the overall gameplay is quite sophisticated.  Unlike games such as Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag, you have to know how to sail with the wind to your advantage.  The size of your sword, ship, and crew matter tremendously as you conquer the West Indies, as well as the hearts of colonial governors' daughters.  You may find yourself chasing ships for game days on end only to lose it to the wind, so you have to be good at assessing situations and using them to your advantage, else the enemy does the same.  Surprisingly, these elements do not detract from the gameplay, but instead add a level of interest and challenge that draws you in further.I'd give it a 9.8out of 10.  It's not perfect, but it's damn close.  My only concern is technical issues (performance), as the game did not run optimally on my system due to the game's slightly antiquated nature.  Even so, the fact that the game IS so old (and this one was a remake) stands as testament to its fantastic ability to entertain.  Any PC gamer should definitely give it a try.

Posted: August 17, 2014
												This is one of my all time favorite games.  A great feel for pirating and lots of different styles of gameplay within it.  Large overarching quests to seek out treasures, opponents, and your family.  Then smaller pieces that make it all up:  Naval combat with a ship you customized and/or captured, dueling and dancing rhytm games, merchant trading (and looting), and even some land based army combat is an option.  The feel of the playthrough changes based on the factions you win favor with or lose, items to collect, and special crewmen to build up.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2014
												Sid Meier has made many games with clever tactical depth, but is not so swollen with rules, so that anybody can jump right in. Pirates! continues the tradition by being a game chock full of strategy, but is highly accessible.The game is a sandbox. You can go anywhere, and do anything, within the Spanish Main. Generally, you plunder ships or towns, and get promoted by friendly nations. There are plenty of other things to do, too.Tasks you perform have an associated action oriented mini-game. You'll be ship-to-ship battling and swordfighting a lot. I like most of these games, though your mileage may vary. Many people have mixed feelings about them.As far as management goes, the game cuts out micro-managing. The action just keeps flowing. The typical mundane busy work of hard-core strategy games is kindly removed here, in order to get to the good bits. There are plenty of strategic decisions to be made, but you get to think in a sense of what you WANT to do, not what you HAVE to do.Certain things are a little tricky to get used to. Sailing East is much harder than sailing West. Your crew slowly becomes restless over time, forcing you to pay them off and take a few months vacation before going back to sailing.After you get to the ripe old age of about 35, your health starts to decline, and you might have to retire before too long. This takes you to an amusing detailed report on your post-pirate life. Hopefully you are a Governor instead of a Pauper!The graphics and sound are cartoony. Everything looks like it's from a Disney/Pixar movie, and the voice acting is done in jibberish, like in The Sims. Subtitles are in English, though. The cartoony feel is not bad, but is sometimes just a little TOO campy.The controls are a bit strange. While you can use a mouse, you're better off doing the mini-games using the numpad. It's a little awkward at first, but you get used to it fairly soon.Pirates! is one of my all time favorite games. Two thumbs and a wooden peg-leg up!

content:
Posted: September 22, 2013
												Pirates! is a game I played quite a bit in college, and playing it again now, it holds up surprisingly well. You play as a Caribbean pirate in a small ship, and you can use it to build up a huge fleet, earn a fortune, find lost cities of gold, and do tons of other things. More than anything else, Pirates! is a sandbox game. It will suggest things to do, but you're free to set your own goals.When you're not sailing, most of the Pirates! gameplay is in the form of mini-games. You'll become very familiar with Fencing... your sword will solve many problems. But you can also participate in naval combat, dance, siege towns, sneak into hostile towns, or hune around the wilderness for treasure. Most of them are short, simple, skill-based games that are incredibly easy on low difficulties, but can get near impossible on the higher ones.The graphics were good for their time, and they've held up better than I expected. The music is nice, but there's not enough of it. The game usually controls well enough.I got this game when it went on sale, and I've been having a lot of fun with it again. I'd wait for a sale to get Pirates!, but when it does, this is a game worth getting.

content:
Posted: October 15, 2011
												This is a terrificly fun, low stress game that gives you the sights and sounds of being a pirate in the caribbean seas circa the 1600's. It plays out like a fast paced board game crossed with an enthusiastic child's fanciful imaginings of the piratey life: all of the highs and none of the lows. It's such a breath of fresh air to play a game that doesn't try to saddle you with a heavy "Hollywood" cinematic story. The encounters are entirely under your control in true sandbox style and you venture through a series of minigames at different locations to obtain information about the placement of notable people, treasures, and upgrades, with each task being fun and easy to grasp.  There's a wealth of things to do with the only drawback being repetition sets in too early; you fight the same pirates, perform the same battle actions, talk to the same placeholder figures over and over again. Give it a shot.  It's fun and frivolous and you'll definintely be entertained.

												This is a great classic. Each successive journey out into the world gives you the opportunity to build your wealth up through attacking ships, raiding towns, finding treasure or just the best buy/sell prices. The higher you set the difficulty, the more loot you get to keep. The fewer crew you have, the more loot there is to go around. content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												An updated edition of an older classic I loved as a kid - I was pumped to find this edition in a bundle, which I picked up for a song. Usually, this game can be found discounted, but is worth a LOT more than a lot of other, more expensive games out there.You're a pirate, you go around capturing and looting ships, rescuing damsels in distress, dancing (it's fun; don't look at me like that), and fencing with other pirates. If you haven't tried it, DO SO.THe only con - difficulty settings are managed in-game, unlike in previous editions, with significant in-game consequences. For some, this can be a little off-putting, especially if you want to jump straight in to a higher difficulty level from the beginning.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												Pirates! is the all the swashbuckling fun a person could want from a pirate-themed video game without being too restrictive. It lays out a basic backstory with optional follow-through, but otherwises allows the player to run wild in the 17th Century Caribbean. At times, however, the game can be a little too hands off in terms of direction (explanation of game and world mechanics and parts of the "storyline"). The controls can a little confusing at first, and I would really recommend a number pad if using a laptop but a mouse is a good alternative also (I've used both and found that while the mouse is more convenient a number pad makes the game much easier to play). Overall, this game is easy to get a hang of quickly and you'll have a fantastic time pirating your way across the high seas.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												Score: 10/10Although Sid Meier's Pirates! is a very old game, it gives the player an unrivaled pirate experience. You are free to make your choices and shape the world in any way you see fit, and that is what I call a true RPG. Which brings us to what I believe is the strongest point of this game, the hability to provide an amazing interaction with the game world, even if you don't realized as you do, as every action brings a reaction somewhere. If you save the merchant ship from the pirates, your allies may prosper, but that very pirate ship that you sunk will be a hard hit in the pirate community. Or, if you are to become the most fiered pirate of the seas, you might find that your pillage is bringing cities to decline.The other mechanics in the game do not present any remarkable point, but been able to have old school ship fight is quite amusing, as well as deciding your batles by your favorite method of combat (ship/sword fight). The graphics and sound are alright and there is no plot, you make your own history.This game deserves a 10 for the great interaction mechanic it carries even being decades old! Definitely a gap to be yet filled.

content:
Posted: July 16, 2012
												Sid Meier's Pirates! is a 2005 remake of the original game he made back in the 1980s. This time, you have better graphics, more advanced swordfighting sequences and more options for everything. You start the game off by leading a mutiny on a merchant vessel. From there on, you can decide whether you want to avenge your family by defeating the Marquis de Montalban, defeating all the major pirate captains in the Spanish Main, accumulate vast amounts of wealth through trade, marry a governor's daughter whether she be sexy or ugly, or if you want to attack merchant ships, plunder seaports and instigate a brand new war. The choice is yours! My only complaint is that you can't customize your character: although he does age, you always have to be the Orlando Bloom type of character. Beyond that, this game is every sandbox adventure you ever dreamed of.
