number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 25, 2014
												Sid Meier's Pirates is one of his best games, alongside Civilization 4 and Civ 5. In this game you can experience the exciting world of the 18th century Caribbean, filled with notorious pirates like Blackbeard, buried treasure, and devastating storms to blow you off course. There are two basic ways you can play the game: You can plunder every single penny from every single person, or you can obey every law there is, and befriend the governor of every town and city on the map. And, of course, you can be somewhere in between. This game has one drawback I will mention: you must have a number pad on your keyboard to play it. Almost everything from sailing your ship to the swordfighting minigames requires the number pad. Aside from that limitation, it is a great game. Not too difficult, but not too easy. I recommend that you purchase this game and try it out for yourself. If you like Sid Meier's other games and you like pirates, you'll like this.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2012
												So much fun!  Pirates doesn't conform to typical genres.  It simply bundles up everything you'd ever want to do if you were a pirate.  Fire the cannons, swashbuckle, plunder, dig for treasure, assemble a fleet, escape from jail, hang out at the tavern, explore the Carribean... seriously, I can think of nothing pirate-related that's not represented.  My biggest gripe is how the protagonist ages.  Unlike Civilization, where the leader reigns for 6000 years and then retires, here your reflexes get worse and worse, making swordfights increasingly frustrating until you're forced to call it quits.  That's not fun, and it's not fair that Marquis Montalban, the final boss, sits in his hideout for eternity, not slowing down over the years even though he was an old man when you were young!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
												Eh, Pirates still is a playable and fun game after all these years, but the many quirks get old quickly. There are a handful of activities to acomplish with a handful of minigames that involvethe numpad, mostly. You can defeat and plunder other ships, sword fight, buy and sell goods, explore the map, track down other notorious individuals, dance with governor's daughters, escort various other ships from town to town, build a skilled crew and search for buried treasure. That sounds like a ton of different things, but it gets repetitive quickly. I like that the game allows you to increase the difficulty level as you deserve it, but when I stopped playing, I realized I  had a bad understanding of the sword fighting mini-game, and has simply bumbled through it at earlier difficulties, and I was having to reload to deal with every other battle, which got really tiring really quickly. I never could find my sister, which was the goal of the game. Maybe I'll reappoach the game with a new character and see if I can be a bit more efficient.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 15, 2011
												This is a terrificly fun, low stress game that gives you the sights and sounds of being a pirate in the caribbean seas circa the 1600's. It plays out like a fast paced board game crossed with an enthusiastic child's fanciful imaginings of the piratey life: all of the highs and none of the lows. It's such a breath of fresh air to play a game that doesn't try to saddle you with a heavy "Hollywood" cinematic story. The encounters are entirely under your control in true sandbox style and you venture through a series of minigames at different locations to obtain information about the placement of notable people, treasures, and upgrades, with each task being fun and easy to grasp.  There's a wealth of things to do with the only drawback being repetition sets in too early; you fight the same pirates, perform the same battle actions, talk to the same placeholder figures over and over again. Give it a shot.  It's fun and frivolous and you'll definintely be entertained.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2011
												I really wanted this game and after a year or two of waiting I bought it.I went through and fully completed the campaign in about twenty to twenty-five hours, so this can last you awhile.There is swashbuckling and ship battles to be had!You can own and command a fleet of ships ranging from a Canoe to a fearsome "Ship Of The Line".When you divide the plunder you can choose to stay at your current naval rank/ game difficulty or get a promotion and slightly increase the game's difficulty. You can also look for buried treasure by purchasing or finding a treasure map.You can attack any ship you see even ones you're supposed to be escorting.You can attack or invade any port or town, to do this,Attack a town with your ship's cannons to kill most of it's men, then invade by land to capture or pillage the town.The graphics are good, music is decent and the dialogue is good aswell.I rate this game, Eight War Canoes Out Of Ten.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2014
												Been wanting a fun pirate game for a while, and since AC Black Flag just didn't do it for me I tried this out.  To my surprise this game is awesome.  Can easily put many hours into it and is simple yet deep and fun.  Totally sandbox, and you can plunder to your hearts desire.  It's definitely a Sid Meier's kinda game, and its old so the graphics and RPG elements are a little dated.  But its definitely worth the small price tag and I would ABSOLUTELY recommend if it was on a steam sale.  However, I truly wish a decent pirate RPG would come out with: leveling, weapons, ship upgrades, custom crew members, sea/land battles, and a good story; as this game sadly is not that.  And that game would most definitely sell.All in all, simple, fun, addictive.  Good purchase.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2014
												Extremely fun, very cute, quality gameplay (for a 2004 title this ran smooth and looked good!!!!!). I can't see myself replaying this, but the single playthrough I did was *very* enjoyable (I received the rank of Mayor, 3rd highest).Gameplay wise you start with your family being wronged and you are able to escape imprisonment and choose to enlist with 1 of 4 nations- the Dutch, the English, the Spanish or the French. You sail around the Carribean and capture ships (or even cities!) of the other nations. You can fight pirates too, including some of the famous ones! Combat involves primarily dueling where you could your opponent's sword move and attack with your own. You may also utilize ship based naval combat by firing off your cannons against other ships with 3 different kinds of shots: your general damage round shot, grape shot to take down crew members, or chain shot to bring down masts & sails. Aside from the combat your goal is to defeat the baddies, gain treasure maps, rescue family members, and even settle down with a lovely wife! =)Bottom line: play it, but ♥♥♥♥ sailing east.

content:
Posted: April 26, 2015
												(This is the 2004 remake of the original game from 1987). Sid Meier's Pirates is a lighthearted swashbuckling romp set during the Age of Discovery.The gameplay basically boils down to a series of minigames; ship-to-ship battles, sword duels, dancing, land battles and treasure hunts.The game is open-ended; there's a 'main quest' of sorts but you can feel free to ignore it if you want. There's plenty of other goals to pursue; find buried treasure, defeat infamous pirates to become the most feared in the Caribbean, track down wanted criminals and collect their bounties, escort ships carrying peace treaties (or betray the nation you're helping and destroy them - war is more profitable than peace for a pirate after all) or just attack everything in sight and amass as much loot as you can.A game won't last forever - your pirate starts the game aged 18 and as time passes in the game he will age and eventually be forced into retirement. If this game has an overall "goal" at all it's to have the highest score you can at the time you retire. The game has difficulty levels; on every playthrough after your first you can choose between them - first time starting a new game, you're forced into the easiest difficulty, though there's a way to change it once you get going, too.Unfortunately, I don't feel like the game has much replay value. The minigames (with the exception of ship battles) are repetitive and shallow and I was burned out on the game before I'd seen everything it had to offer (I completed the "main quest", went after all the named pirates and then lost interest). The harder difficulty settings feel more frustrating than genuinely challenging, too.Still, I got 25 hours of fun out of this game for £6, so I'd say I got my money's worth; I recommend it.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 2, 2015
												I like this game but the age really limits it's mechanics. It becomes very samey after a few hours. I feel like if there was a sequel to this game made today, it would be really great. So ill list all the bad points first.-Ship travel is often SLOW as hell. Especially if you have to travel against the wind (which never changes direction). It could have done with a minimum speed cap based on the ship you have.-Basic sword fighting. The sword fights are all the same and are quickly cheesed with fast attacks.-Not much to do. You can marry a daughter (one), Kill 9 other pirates, rank up with each faction, tresure hunt, and do  the main story line. Sounds like a lot on paper but then you realize killing pirates are the same as fighting any other person in the game, Ranking up is exactly the same in each faction, each daughter requires the same exact things, and the main story is mostly more pirate hunting stuff. Its extremly limited in variation.-There really isnt much of a story anyway. Its got open world-itus which means you can go anywhere at anytime but there isnt any structure. The pacing is god awful. and it takes forever to get to the next story point. In the 6 hours I have played (never played it before) I got to the highest rank in the english faction as well as midway in the other 3, killed all other 9 pirates, had married a daughter and romanced 4 others high enough to marry if I wasnt already, Saved 3 family members in the main story (which involves killing the SAME guy over and over) and gotten most of the items in the game.All that said though, I did enjoy myself for the most part. The only part I really hated was just how slow ship travel is which would entail me watching a video on another screen while my ship traveled across the map for 10 minutes. I do think its worth picking up if its on sale for very cheap and I do think you will have a decent time with it for a few hours.Its just held back due to the time period it was released in. Unfortunatley the mechanics dont hold up as well in this day and age. Im surprised a sequel hasnt been made yet seeing the love for the ship battles in Assassins Creed Black Flag though. I feel like it would do wonderfully in the market right now.

content:
Posted: December 9, 2016
												Should we accept a classic as a classic after the era it became a classic in stops being classic? This is the classic question that I would love to finally classify and I shall provide a vintage standard and time-honoured solution to this problem. Pirates, classically, are known as the typical scurge of the usual seven seas we are all familiar with. However, this classification is typically unjust. Sid Meier's classic experience, Pirates! focuses on the most representative of all classical periods of piracy, namely the Golden Age in the Caribbean of pre 1730 vintage. I want to point out that typically, a classic pirate crew of this day would not be a simble group of your usual scoundrels, but in fact much closer to the democratic nature of classical liberals. While I don't believe that the classic game Sid Meier's Pirates! represents this class of pirates in a standard manner, it does make a good attempt at showing how Piracy was a reasonable and standard career choice in this era.Now for the typical pros and cons;+Classic arcade combat+Classic lost family story line+Classic famous pirates (collect the skulls of all 9)+Classic ship designs +Classic game-Classic repetitive gameplay-Classic ugly charachter models-Classic scurvyOverall, this game is a classic that still stands the test of time. A true classic for video games!

content:
Posted: May 4, 2016
												No other game stole so many hours of my childhood.  Well, maybe Rollercoaster Tycoon Gold, but that's besides the point!  This timeless open-world sand-- er, waterbox-- gives you a ship and wishes you well, then reels in the anchors to let you do whatever the hell you want.  Sure, you could be a hero and save your family from slavery at the hands of an evil and abusive Marquis, but... why would you?  There's only so much time in your simulated pirate life, time that could be used to board Spanish trade galleons, to sack cities, to find ancient Incan ruins, to deliver ultimatums, to conquer all in the name of the Dutch, to beat up drunk tavern regulars, to buy treasure maps and moustaches from Sid Meier in the back corner of the tavern, to marry sixteen governors' daughters through your ballroom dancing swagger, to do whatever the hell you want!YAR HAR DIDDLY DEE, BEING A PIRATE IS ALRIGHT TO BE, DO WHAT YOU WANT CAUSE A PIRATE IS FREE, YOU ARE A PIRATE!

content:
Posted: March 21, 2015
												Where to start..... Unlike alot of these reviewers, i had not played this before, i walked into this game completely blind. So, the fact that theres no nostaligia involved here, my review is for those who have never played or heard of this game before. Theres no tutorial or manual to speak of, but to be honest this game dosnt really need one. Its an rpg, so if youve palyed previous rpgs like me, you'll have a basic understanding of what your doing. If you havnt played one before then this would be an excellent first choice. So, your thrust into this open world pirate game with nothing but a back story, which i might add is not narrated in the slightest. In fact, i think the reason theres so much content in this game is because they didnt do any voice acting AT ALL. Theres just mostly grunts or the wooing of ladies for "dialog". But besides the lack of voice acting, the game is damn near perfect. There is SO much to do in this world. Without any spoilers, You have to save your family, become a top notch pirate, track down criminals, defeat pirates based off of real life ones such as Captain Kidd and Black Beard, pillage ships, raids towns, dance with the ladies, ship battles, fleet managments, sell plunder, buy food stocks, get unique items, upgrade your ship, get special crew members, conquer cities in a board game like rts mode, search for buried treasure, get promotions, gain land, ect. And thats probably half of what there is. At this point im only 10 hours in the game and i have already done all of that, and there is just so much more to do. If your a fan of pirates or Rpgs, GET THIS GAME AND GET IT NOW!!! It's only 10 dollars for so so SO much content, and the replayability is off the charts! Do yourself a favor, and buy this game and pray they make another one!

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												Arrr me maties! To this date the best game for you to become the most badass pirate ever! Beautiful sandbox-like gameplay, a true gem, sadly overlooked by many people. I really don't have much to criticize - perhaps the lack of a proper story. But what the game has to offer (which is sailing around with ships, battling others, duels, sieging cities and many other things) is really good.And unlike Assassins Creed 4, there is actually kinda realistic morale element where your crew can revolt when you're too long at sea, or you're not very succesful pirate. Game itself is easy to jump in, but certainly provides more than a decent challenge.Ship ahoy!

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												This is basically Mount and Blade's campaign mode but instead of visceral, gory combat holding the whole thing together, we have pirate-themed quicktime event minigames. And yet, it works! I found the lack of variety pretty stunting around hour 4 though, and I doubt I'll finish it. In the ~five hours I played I completed about 10% of the actual main storyline (granted, I spent almost all that time ♥♥♥♥in' around). So, uh, yeah. If you liked running from camp to camp, building up an army, gearing them up, then watching as they all get taken away in one ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t battle, you can do that here. Except, y'know, no battle. Pirate minigame.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												Let me start off by saying that I love this game so much that I almost felt like I was cheating on my wife when I bought it anew last night. I bought it on the day that it originally came out, and spent actual DAYS playing the game, only stopping to eat, bathe, and go to the bathroom. I don't think that I slept more than eight total hours in that first week, and my name was known, loved, and feared throughout the Caribbean. More so than in any other Sid Meier game before or since, I was completely engulfed by this game to the point of addiction.Then, you know, life (and other games) happened.So, flash forward a few years and I saw that it was on Steam. How well did it hold up? Would I fire it up, laugh at the dated gfx and gameplay, never to play again? Would it be like I'd never stopped playing and find myself engulfed into the game again? I downloaded it last night, and have already racked up seven, almost eight hours. Gfx and some clunky and (now) counter-intuitive gameplay aside, I still love this game and thought it was absolutely worth the $10 to buy it again. It's just as fun as I remembered, although I do confess that I still hate the dancing portion of the game! Absolutely recommended!My only REAL gripe is with the sound. It's not that it's dated, it's just that when you're playing the game, you have no choice but to either turn off the sound altogether OR you're forced to listen to the same... jaunty... pirate... ditties... again... and... again... and... Imagine being forced to listen to the sound of a dentist's drill or your favorite child's death rattle on infinite loop - this is the quality of the music. While you can go into the system properties and turn off the music, that's only the music for cut scenes and the like - the in-game music is tied irrevokably to the sound effects, so no cannonfire, no sound of the wind... unless you're willing to listen to monkey-grinder music.

content:
Posted: May 8, 2015
A classic. One of my favorite games of all time.Personal overall rating: 9/10I've played this game for almost 9 years now! Just got it on my computer a few days ago and, wow... It's so much better. I first played it on Xbox, then psp, then got it for my 360, and now have it for my computer. Of course, this is the best version of the game. ALL HAIL THE MASTER RACEOPTIONS MENU:The Video settings has 9 options. Picture Gamma, Water Detail, Object Detail, World Detail, Resolution, Shadows, Advanced Lighting, Trillinear Filtering, & Shaders. It's an old game, most computers will be able to handle it with the settings turned up relatively high. The Audio Settings has a Master Volume slider, Music Volume, Sound FX Volume, Dance Music Volume, and a 3D Sound Driver toggle. The Modify Ship's Sails and Flags option changes your ship's flag appearance and the logo/crest on your main sail. There's 6 crests/logos for your sail. 1.Dutch: Greater Coat of Arms of The Netherlands, 2.English: St George Crest, 3.French: Royal Coat of Arms of The Kingdom of France, 4.Indians: Tribal Tiki Logo, 5.Pirates: Jolly Roger Crest, 6.Spanish: Coat of Arms of Toledo.There are 5 flags, the Flags are 1.Dutch: Orange flag with a green xing emblem, 2.English: White flag with a red St George cross, 3.French: Blue flag with a gold Flour De Les emblem. 4.Pirates: Black flag with a white Jolly Roger. 5.Spanish: Yellow flag with a black Royal Lion. GRAPHICS:It's an old game. It's not exactly pretty. The game looks best while you're out sailing. There is noticeable aliasing, mushy textures, and choppy animations. The water refelction is decent. The explosion effect during ship battles when cannonballs make contact and when ships explode is awesome. It's the game's strongest point graphically. The way the colors of the sea blend together is nice as well. STORY:The story is kind of weird. An evil Spanish nobleman (the Marquis de la Montalbán) interupts a dinner party consisting of you and your family. Your family is in debt to him. When you see him, you immediatley know he has bad intentions, so you bolt passed him through the door. He takes your family. They become slaves. You survive on your own for the next 10 years. You begin your young adulthood joining a faction (Dutch, English, French, or Spanish). You serve on a ship where a cruel captain is in charge. Tired of being abused and insulted by the captain, you and your mates rally up and form a mutiny against him. You boot him from the ship, and take charge. You're the captain now, and realize this is the perfect opportunity to find your lost family. PLAYING THE GAME:Sailing is a ton of fun. The feeling of adventure you get from cruising the sea is so satisfying. Playing a game that isn't the same copy paste recipe as every other game in itself is extremely satisfying. There's open sea adventure, epic ship battles, duels, city invasions, sneaking through hostile towns, treasure hunting, pirate hunting, and the wonderful ability to do whatever you want. Live the pirate life your way. You can gain new items for your character like dual pistols and some well crafted swords. You can aquire new ships and give them upgrades. You can even name your ships as well as your character of course. You'll be addressed by your character's name by the other people in the game. They address you by your surname, so when creating your character make sure you name them by their last name. Anyways but yea, that's the game. You build up your crew, and become the deadliest pirate to ever live. Please try the game. It's cheap, it's fun. You'll enjoy it. Please just try it.

content:
Posted: May 18, 2014
												This is one of the best pirate themed video games ever made, and the game that most pirate themed games end up taking their inspiration from. It's easy to pick up and play yet there's a lot of complexity here too. From bounties to allegiances to trading there are a lot of things you can do here yet you can also just sail around capturing ships & pillaging. The main thing I like about this is the fact that no matter what you do you never feel bored. You never run out of stuff to do, and you're always accomplishing stuff. Goals can be challenging but they're never so impossible that they get too frustrating. This is a great title that will challenge you and even if you fail at a challenge it never punishes you for it. It gives you many chances to come back later when you're more prepared for it. All in all one of the best games I've ever played, and certainly one of the best pirate games ever.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2016
												Disappointing.  I really want to like this game but it has some issues.  There are some bugs that can pop up and make life annoying, such as getting stuck different places in your ship.  For example, I was captured and then bribed my way out of Havana.  My ship ended up on the opposite side of the island, glued to the shore.  No way to get off the beach.  Only thing to do is go to last save point.  I've also been trapped near towns with sand bars near, having to constantly answer the pop up "do you want to anchor or sail away?" while attempting to navigate away in the split second allowed.  Game is really, really simple.  Kind of surprising, given Sid Meier's other games.  Overly simple/devoid of features in many ways.  Can't do anything with land you're granted.  Can't invade enemy towns unless they have a garrison.  Can only attack convoys with one ship at a time, no matter how many ships you have.  Convoy gets all ships.  You can accidentally sell the cannons off your ship and end up defenseless.  If enemies capture a ship of yours, you can't capture it back, it just disappears.

number of helpful: 15 of 47 people (32%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 19, 2015
												I heard so much about this game and I love Civilization that I had to try it.  It was meh.  I think nostalgia clouds too many minds on how wonderful this game is.  It's not bad, it just isn't all that special. There isn't a real storyline (they kind of make a basic quest of finding your family which isn't very exciting) and maybe that would have spiced the game up for me.  I love a good story.  It just throws you in there and you just start living the life of a pirate captain which is great if you don't like being shackled to linear game play.  Felt like a chore going back and forth on the map at a snail's pace and I just wasn't having fun.  I gave up after realizing how many times I had to trek back and forth and I didn't want to waste my time with it.  I feel like this would work as a casual game on a mobile device that you could play for a bit, put it down, and pick it up later.  The dancing sequences are annoying, the sword fights are all the same and get boring, and trying to catch the wind in your sails was♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥me off.  I feel there are more engaging choices out there.

number of helpful: 32 of 86 people (37%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												Though I put quite a few hours into this game my lasting impression is that it's not very enjoyable.  The concept itself is good, but the game becomes very repetitive and the play balance on harder difficulties is completely bonkers.  Late game on Rogue difficulty I lost a ship to only three hits, when fighting other ships of the same type I would hit them twenty times or more before they would sink.  The AI gets special abilities like attacking you on the strategic map, and the late "quests" of endgame are simply finding and fighting the same guy over and over again until you get a map to go and fight him again in some place in the middle of no where. And while the game has a lot of "mini-games", man of these are simply not compelling.   The game has a lot of content but all that content is ultimately light on depth, and despite playing the game to its conclusion and getting a Fame score of 106 my "victory" was little more than a page of text.  Why not a simple cinematic?If you get it cheap, play it, then go on to something with more enduring quality and depth.

number of helpful: 8 of 31 people (26%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 25, 2016
												Hahaha, these upset fangirls.  I guess the truth does hurt.I should've stopped playing this a couple hours in, but I wanted to give the game a chance to get better.  It's too bad that it never does.Let's start with what looks good about this game.  Decent sized world, four nations to work for/against to gain rank, NPC ships attack one another, nations declare war and peace against one another, nations capture each others ports, many types of ships, freedom to do what you want, trading, pirating, making a fleet, sword fighting, romance, treasure hunting, rescuing family, finding lost cities, storms at sea, crew mutinies, bringing down pirates, and even other stuff.  It sounds awesome.  It's too bad most of the things that happen are pointless and half of the game is tedious minigames.I'd say about 50% of your time will be spent playing the minigames, so lets start with them.  There are several minigames including sea battles, sword-fights, dancing, land navigation, sneaking, and ground battles.  Most of the minigames you'll play will be the first three.  They're ok at first, but you'll play those same minigames over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over.  Did you get tired of reading that? That's how I felt about those first three minigames after playing them 15 times.  Then realize in a playthrough that you'll play those three anywhere from 60-100+ times.  Imagine playing Mario Party, except it only has 6 mediocre minigames, and it only selects 3 of those minigames 90% of the time.  Then play that Mario Party for 10-13 hours.  That's what playing through Sid Meier's Pirates feels like.  I have absolutely no idea how anyone could tolerate multiple playthroughs of this mindless dreck.The other 50% of the time spent sailing would've been alright, except for the wind.  Do you like sailing west?  No worries, because the wind has got your back.  At some point though, you're going to need to sail back east.  You will.. do... this.... at.... a.... snail's.... pace.... against.... the.... wind.... Oh... here... comes... a... cloud... to.. speed me back up and.. it's... gone.... Time.... to.... take.... a.... nap....  I hated sailing anywhere in the west.  There were times when I'd set sail east, walk out of the room for a bit, come back, and still not be at my destination.  Nothing interesting ever happens while you're out at sea either.  You'll never be in danger of running out of food.  I often had multiple years worth of food from sacking ships.  I'd go into ports selling it off.  It's cool to see a Treasure Ship or Military Payroll for the first time, but by the 5th time, it's not quite so exciting, and by the 10th time, you won't even bother plundering them unless it keeps your crew from going to mutiny status.  The most exciting thing that happens out on the sea is accidentally running into one of the main quest enemies.  This is only exciting because it saves you 10 minutes of boredom finding out where they're headed and spending time tracking them down.  Also somewhat annoying is that occasionally the game will launch you out of a port straight into some rocks which damage your ship.  If you have a large fleet, instead of following your path, they do their own thing.  This often includes taking damage when they sail into rocks that you manuevered around but they decided would make an excellent path.I could've probably tolerated all of that stuff if the rest of the game made up for it, but it doesn't.  The game has no objective and nothing you do matters.  Doesn't matter whether you save your family, or rank up with each nation, or take out all the top pirates or do anything.  The game ends whenever you feel like it should end and retire.  One nation declares war or peace on another nation, doesn't impact you at all.  NPC ship sinks another npc ship, it'll respawn.  One nation conquers another nation's port, doesn't matter, can still sail in there and do all the same things I could've done anyway.  Pirates sack a port, doesn't matter.  Want to buy some of the cool stuff that guy in the corner sells, crew gets mutinous.  Amass a nice fleet, doesn't matter, only your flagship fights in battles and your crew will become mutinous and you'll have to divide the plunder and go back to 1 ship anyway.  You're the top pirate in the land, doesn't affect a thing.  Saved all your family, does nothing.  Want to save your family?  Have fun hunting down Baron Raymondo and waiting for him to respawn 12-16 times to get all the maps pieces.  Have fun sword fighting that same guy behind the bar 25 times that the dancing minigame gives you as a quest.  I completed most of the main objectives, aside from nation ranks, but gave up and retired when my wife expected me to dance with her 8 more times for the rest of the lost city map pieces.Maybe the problem is that I played Uncharted Waters on the Sega Genesis and know what a good pirate game should be.  This entire game is a tedious grind where nothing you do matters.

												An old game with old game problems.Some minor bugs with Steam and DirectX that can be easily fixed.The main problem is the lack os native widescreen support. There is a couple of fixes available, but if you apply any of them, the HUD, some buttons and texts stays partially off screen. If that isn't bad enough, to click on some buttons you'll need to click outside then for them to work. It gets very frustrating to play this way.If you don't apply the resolution fix, you get stuck with 4:3 aspect ratio resolutions and using this with widescreen, everything will get stretched.

												Not sure why this gets so many great reviews but I just didn't like this game and if it were possible I would have looked into a refund. I guess I wanted to raise a pirate fleet and take over the seas, micromanage the ships and crews and had combat be a bit more interesting than this. No fast travel either. It's cheap and if you got little kids then buy this but if you are looking for a more realistic pirate experience this isn't it.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
												It blows my mind how this gets any positive reviews. I suppose everything will have it's lovers and haters. Count me in the latter category.I typically love Sid Miere's games too. NEVER have I run into more outdated controls in my life. Even playing it at moderate difficulty levels I found this "game" to be more stress-inducing than a flight being canceled at the busiest airport while being forced to take two final exams in chemistry and 16th Century Literaure all at the same time. CONS:- The AI will generally always counter your sword attacks, while countering it's own requires PRECISE timing or else. - Adapts and speed up dance challenges, to the point where the odds of winning are slim to none.- You'll generally ALWAYS be placed upwind in ship battles, making manuvering nigh impossible. Meanwhile, AI ships will dance circles around you- The winds tend to blow extremely fast in one direction (west in my experience) making travel in the opposite direction very tedious and time-consuming.PROS:- Immersive, the general atmosphere is great- The music is simple but lovely- Fun, when the difficulty is balanced [usually never] (even at lower difficulties it's an imbalanced game)All in all I can't say I enjoyed my time with this title. In fact, I believe it gave me muscle cramps due to the stress it induced. I'm glad I only spent $2.50 on it during a sale, but I can say it was $2.50 wasted

content:
Posted: April 24, 2015
												Ugh, so much abou this game drives me CRAZY, but so much of it is fun too. The fun part is mostly due to open-world sandbox play, with no scripted gameplay, you can just sail around and do what you want. The good is pretty good. The bad is absolutely a deal breaker, though. The dancing thing with the governor daughter is impossible on the PC. I played this to death on the Xbox with no problems but this stupid PC version gives you 1/10th of a second to respond to the dancing bullcrap which made that part of the game unbelievably frustrating--on par with the buggy SM Railroads. The ships get stuck on land masses and LAUNCH like a rocket out of ports so you have to hit pause every time you leave a port. ANNOYING! In summary, it's too buggy and annoying for repeat play. the old Xbox version of possibly iPad version are better choices for this game. This PC original is not worth playing.

content:
Posted: March 22, 2015
												I wish ratings was not yes or no. Im giving it a no just because the ratings are too high. See, it is a great game for its time. But theres a few annoying parts. It cant be called an adventure game because you are restricted to the caribean and you do not feel like an adventurer. Not the improved 'uncharted waters' I hoped for. The challenge is too wimpy at first- get your attack speed up and mash buttons in duels to win every battle- then becomes too hard. But most annoying of all there is no tutorials. I have played this long and became #1 pirate, and dont know HTF dueling (the main thing in the game) even works, the controlls seem to suck. Dancing seemed impossibly hard. Granted I am playing as adventurer captain (hard difficulty) but that stuff should have been explained by the time I finished my 6th pirating carreer. You cant really customize your ship. And trading stinks, you really cant make any money at it. For the record I do recommend it anyways if it is on sale.Some things I find quite great is the ship to ship battles take a lot of skill, and has quite a lot of depth. And when you attack a town the game turns into a nearly full strategy game.If I or anyone else could mod the game for even a few months, it would be great. But as is it just slightly below wonderfull, just a collectors item from another time.

number of helpful: 11 of 58 people (19%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2014
												So much promise but age and/or operating systems have brought down what Pirates could be.The first problem I encountered was an absolutely ridiculous graphical glitch with the sails and flags of the ships. I would boil it down to a physx issue, but I don’t think that technology even existed when Pirates was released. Basically what would happen is that when the wind blew a certain direction, any fabric on screen would stretch to infinity and obscure 60-70% of the screen. The next issue I had was that for some reason the primary method of control (awkwardly using the number pad) straight up did not work. I tried a different keyboard as well as an old PS2 board and neither allowed any of the diagonal buttons to register.I’m not a computer genius or anything, but I can’t imagine all the technical problems I had running the game being anything more than driver issues and modern operating system changes. If you have an older XP system I bet this game is amazing, from the little bit I suffered through, there was so much awesome content. But if you own a modern gaming computer, just be aware that this game may not play nice with your setup.

number of helpful: 14 of 67 people (21%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 20, 2014
												Maybe I don't get this game, or it just wasn't running properly on my computer. A slow and choppy game, Pirates is a baisc open world Pirate game where you sail around trading and plundering.The trade mechanic worked fairly identically to most games with a trade mechanic, and was fine, but the actual pirate battles were fairly lackluster, mostly involving a bit of maneuvering and a whole lot of patience. While you can build up a fleet of ships, this is mostly for maximizing your cargo capacity, and not really for getting increases in combat bonuses (at least as far as I could tell). You can only ever bring one ship into battle, which kept the gameplay very light. If there is depth to be found in this game, I was too frustruated by the incredibly slow pacing to find it.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												It's not that this is an old game, it's that this game isn't very good.  Gameplay is instantly repetitive and dull, very little risk, all reward, but no real action.  Sea battles make no sense, guns don't matter, all you do is ram the ship, hit a few buttons to defeat the captain, loot.  Dancing with girls mini game is just silly.  Mechanics make no sense.  Split loot disbands your fleet and you lose all your money?  Why would you ever do that?  Retire ends the game?  Why would you ever do that?  No clear benefits to upgrading ships, again because all you do is ram other ships and duel.  No clear point to hiring more men, just more mouths to feed for no reason.  Overall, just a terrible game that you throw away after half an hour.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 24, 2015
												In this game you take a role of privateer or pirate. You can work for either English, French, Dutch or Spanish - or even for all of them if you time your actions well. There's constantly changing basic economic and political system where player's actions do affect on the bigger picture as well. You can sail, capture ships, fight pirates, trade, do missions, dance with governors daughters and so on. There's many goals to fullfill and many ways to play. Because there's different eras to choose from and the world is open, dynamic and reactive the gaming experience does change lot. There's also different difficulty levels which do have effect. Game's replayability value is quite high and you can get it cheaply, especially on sale. Technically speaking I have been playing this game for something like 30 years from it's early versions on Commodore 64. From those early days they have added more content and huge haul in graphics but the core is same. And it works. Still one of the best, if not best, pirate games there are.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2015
												I was playing Pirates! for a year after it came out on PSP. I borrowed it as often as I could from the library and played so much I recognized where every treasure could spawn at from one scrap of the map. I would dedicate entire days to me lying on the couch, trying to sack a new town for the Dutch. I became so skilled that I wouldn't be slowed on the hardest difficulty.However, even with all of that work, I never 100% completed the game. It's so easy to get caught up in the politics, treasure hunting, intregue, and dancing. This game can keep you so busy that you'll be retired before you know it.The only way for this game to be made better is to release an HD remake (or sequal) with some minor adjustments:Improved graphics (better textures, water effects, etc)Improved framerate (60+ would be ideal)Custom keybinding and controller supportModding support Other than that, it's a really good game. 9/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
												Sid Meier's PiratesOne thing I can say is get it. The game is hours of fun. Granted very repetitive but very fun.You play as a Pirate with a Privateer contract with the Empire you first sail with (England, France or Spain). You can choose the raid any of the countries ports in the Caribbean. The option is to amass your wealth and get promoted to have a variety of different types of women (governors daughters that can be your wife). Plain, Pretty and Beautiful. The women you impress by not only acquiring rank with the Empire involved but also getting little gifts. The option is to also save your family and avenge what happened to them to force you to be a privateer. Or do both at the same time. Like I said before the gameplay can be repetitive as can the mini-games inside such as the sword fighting or the dancing mini-games. But this is a game you can literally play for hours and not notice the time lapse. I have outside of steam having owned it for years before the disc didn't work properly. A must buy game well worth the price

content:
Posted: December 6, 2015
												I have always loved this game, it's a pretty simple game that isn't very challenging, but I love it.Pros:•Wont matter for a lot of people, butvery little mouse input needed, great for playing on the bus, or somewhere where I don't have an external mouse with my laptop•Graphics still hold decently well, the animations are a bit laughable, but the graphics don't hurt my eyes.•Very little story.  While the game does have a story, it doesn't push you into doing it at all, so your free to do whatever you want. Considdered a pro, because a lot of simular games like this force you to do the main storyline, and limit the open-world.Cons:•Some of the minigames can get a bit reppetitive. Dancing is very important in the game, but is not very fun, and I hate sneaking into towns. The most common ones like sword-fighting or ship battles stay fun.•Not very difficult. Even on swashbucking difficulty (the hardest one) the only thing I have trouble with is a few sword fights, but if you use the cutlass and taunt often, they aren't a problem.Overall, this game deffinetly is not for everyone. I have always loved this style of game, so it's easy for me to love this game. The game isn't very expensive, especially on sale, so I would whole-heartedly recomend picking it up if it looks even slightly appealing to you.

number of helpful: No ratings yet2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 10
												This game--- oh Lordy have mercy, this game! Going into 'Sid Meier's Prirates!', I had the impression it was going to be an overall decent experience, but without much direction. The game has a story, but, in my first few minutes, I had feared it'd be too open-ended and not give me much to go on. Wrong.You're set out proper into the ocean with a decent crew, a small ship and a good six or so months worth of food, and are tasked with finding your captured family. While this may seem daunting, seeing as there are sixteen greek family members to all track down, it's surprisingly simple to start the story. Simply make your mark by capturing a few easy ships, do some quests for some governers and such-- before you know it, you're hunting down pirates, treasure, merchant vessles and everything of the sort, easy peasy!The game is wonderfully simple to get into, and it kept me hooked for hours. Couldn't stopl playing unit I demended to myself "Go eat something and finish your homework--- THEN you'll have EVEN MORE time to play!" And so I'm writing this review eating one heck of a tuna sandwich, if I do say so myself. It's got parsley and mayo in-- I put lettice and some mango on it, and a little bit of hidden valley ranch---The game.It's awesome.If you're looking for a light-hearted but still involved pirate game where you carve out a ledgend other pirates will envy, this is the game for you! Fluid mechanics, everyhting feels wonderful to do-- just... I waited for a sale-- and this was undoubtedly some of the best three bucks of my life. Usually 10 but heck-- I'd say it's totally worth it, there's just so much to be had!

												Ah Sid Meier how you love to make people waste their entire day away on just one video game. He does it well that's for sure, and Pirates (Next to civilization) Shows this better than anything. With this 2004 release being the best.Pros:-Very Piratey...Yohohoho.-Capturing, Plundering, and Digging up treasure never gets old.-The game let's you increase the difficulty the farther you get in the game-Restoring your family feels good-There's a good amount of upgrades-Pillaging Towns is the best part in my view. This game never gets boring, and the difficulty levels are sufficient to either give you a leisurely stroll through the Caribbean or a truly gripping fight at sea. Highly recommend it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												This is an old game, but I gotta say, it's a good one.I got the urge to play some kinda pirate simulation game a while back, and there has just been nothing out on the market like that of late, unless you're into Assassin's Creed.. which I'm not. (because Ubisoft.)  But I found this on sale for a few bucks.. and thought.. Ok.. Pirates.. Sid Meier.. sure, why not.  It was a good choice.Lots of things you can do..different goals you can try for.  The mechanics are somewhat simplistic.. I mean, it's a 2004 remake of a 1987 game, so you can't expect too much sophistication out of it..  But that said, if you're looking for something to swash your buckle.. (or would that be buckle your swash?), this'll do it.  The minigame mechanics for fencing and dancing are easy at the lowest difficulty, but get quite challenging at higher ones unless you've got good "twitch gamer" reflexes... So most of us will find a decent challenge available.The AI does some strange things at times.. that's pretty much to be expected..   Like in my latest playthrough, I decided to be a English pure "privateer".. following the terms of my "Letter of Marque and Reprisal"..  Drove the French and the Dutch completely out of the Caribbean, and the Spanish are down to just a half a dozen cities on the coast of Mexico and Central America..  The last French and Dutch cities to fall, and the last Spanish city on the northern islands, all responded by sending invasion force after invasion force, sometimes 3 or 4 frigates at once laden with troops.. over and over.. out of cities with barely any money or troops due to my blockade..  which, of course, would be impossible with any sense of "realism"..But that doesn't detract from the fun. In fact, it makes it even more amusing.. "How can I get the AI to freak out this time?" becomes it's own sort of meta-game.  At least for me. I personally would *love* to see a *sequel* to this game.. not a HD remake, or a relaunch.. but a full Pirates! 2.  Updated engine, graphics.. merging geopolitics into it a bit borrowing elements from the Civilization series.. Really treating the naval situation and piracy in the region during that time as it was historically... a proxy war between the competing empires of Europe..  Character development maybe, a skill tree, so you get better at your skills along with upgrading gear, instead of just getting bonuses from equipment..  More promotion options, etc..  The ability to have actual fleet combat, and the ability to found your own colonies...But probably the only actual real *downside* to this game.. is that I haven't figured out how to actually be the aggressor against a foreign city... the only way I've found so far is to just look and sink a whole bunch of their ships till the harbor guns get♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥enough to take a pot shot at you.. then you get the option to "attack"..  I wanna bombard em from sea, then unleash the pirate hordes.. lol..But even with that annoyance, and the limitations of this being a very old remake of an even older game.. it's a classic.. Revolutionary for it's time, and has aged quite well. Give it a try.

content:
Posted: April 17, 2015
												Sidmeier's Pirates is a remake of an older version of the Game and ticks all the boxes right for doing so. Having said that. I have 10.5 hours in it and finished it - that said higher difficulties from the start are still open to me, as you are obligated to start at the easiest difficulty when you first start the game but you can during the game up the difficulty by 'dividing the loot'.It has several 'mini-games' including dancing/romancing governor daughters, attacking cities, and fighting on ships. These mini-games are not overly hard, but not too difficult that is just a breeze. As you can interspace them the way you want the mini-games are never bothersome, in my opinion.The atmosphere and humor of the game is its major selling point and as such it a good little game for a bit of relaxing. And with the difficulties, different starting eras, and starting proficiencies you can definately make it harder on yourself to get a more challenging experience should you wish it, but to me it does not seem as if it was created to make you have deep low and mountain peak highs, but rather a relaxing giggle.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 17, 2015
												A fun pirate game set in the Caribbean, during the 17th Century. You are a privateer looking to make his fortune and rescues if lost family. It is an early open world game, in that although there is a notional storyline, in practice you tend to end up sailing the seas, capturing or sinking ships with impunity whilst leaving your family to rot in captivity. The gameplay is not only confined to sailing the ocean blue, there is a host other (nefarious) activities to take part in, ranging from sacking cities and copious amounts of swordplay to wooing the daughters of cites governors with your masterful dancing skills. The controls are simple to pick up, although can hard to master are higher difficulty levels – a case in point is the dancing. At low difficulty you are given clear guides to which button to press. This becomes subtle hand gestures at higher levels, easy to miss as you stumble around the dancefloor like you have had too much grog. Graphically it is pretty to look at, without be Assassins Creed Black Flag. Bear in mind this was first released in 1987. It has been updated for modern OS but is still more functional than flashyGameplay	8Graphics	        6Control		7Fun		        8Overall		7.5

												All you need to know about Pirates.This game was released in a similar form in the early 1990's called Pirates Gold for Sega Genesis.One day I started playing in my crappy college apartment as my roomate was leaving to go home for the weekend. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 29, 2015
												Sid Meier's: Pirates! is an amazing game. I highly enjoy playing it, and I most definitely recommend this game to others, especially to those who loves open world and RPG games.  This game has a lot of mechanics to play with, and the varieties are just endless! There is also some element of tactic and strategy: to get the wind on your side so you can sail faster than other ships, turning your ship to the right angle to bombard your enemies with cannon balls, and position your pirates and buccaneers at strategic positions to overwhelm ports and cities! Or you can just brute force everything, like ramming your ship into enemy ships and hack the captain to pieces! Works too! However, don't expect too much from the stories, as they are slightly repetitive and there isn't too much about the main story of the game. But I definitely recommended the game.Positive:-Lots of things you can do! Recruit crews, take other ships, chase down criminals, romance governors' daughters, find treasures, attack ports, and many more!-You can play the absolute balls out of this game. As if the main quests isn't long enough, you can do many other side quests, like hunting down notorious and famous pirates, hunting for treasure, and finding lost cities. You can also do things for your personal achievement, like becoming the most famed pirate and advancing through the ranks in a faction.Even then, you still can increase the difficulty and add more challenge! Or, you can just retire early, and divide the plunder with your crew.-Variety. There are many different kinds of ships that you can sail, be it a war sloop, a war galleon, a trade galleon, a simple indian canoe, and many more! Add various upgrades to your ship. Be nasty to the European kingdoms by wrecking their ships and sacking their ports, or rise through the ranks as the admiral of the European fleet! Hire (force them to join your crew by sinking the ship they were on and leaving them with no choice) various specialists to aid you in your journey. Choose a weapon to duel against your enemies!Negative:-The plot of Sid Meier's: PIrates! is not too rich. The story is quite repetitive, and may seem boring after a while. Tossing notorious pirates into the sea only to see them magically reappear alive and well while rising through the top 10 pirates list is not the smoothest of things.-Expect not HD high quality graphics. The graphics excellent considering the time when the game was made, and it is bright, cheery and colorful, but it is starting to show its age.-Gameplay might be repetitive after a while. Capturing ships over and over with no other things to do left gets boring. The mechanics of sailing and taking over ports are also dramatically simplified, and it is certainly no sailing simulator.Recommended, 9/10.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
												This game...it's hard to describe it exactly in an overarching view.Let me go ahead and talk about the factions in this game.Spain: Huge amounts of land and ships, but the ships suck and the land cities are heavily guarded. Ships are usually huge, but slow, and have a huge amount of crew, but the ships seem like they are made out of cardboard. Has most cities in the game. Also, the Spanish are at war with everyone almost all the time.England: Sloops and Brigs as far as the eye can see! England has some of the fastest ships, and remember how I said the Spanish ships are made of cardboard? Well, the English cannons fire the equivalent of napalm in a ball when hitting a Spanish ship. Besides the Spanish, they have the most amount of cities, although most are islands and not on the mainland Americas.France: The French have some what I'd consider all around style of ships. They are a mix of ships and power, but they work. They have less than the English, but aren't doing the worst.Netherlands/Dutch: "Oh sweet almighty Jesus, we are screwed," is probably what you'd think if you were the Dutch king. Basically, the Dutch aren't exactly doing the best when it comes to amount of land or types of ships, but it's much easier to buy and sell in Dutch markets, as well as get promotions. Basically, you want more recruits and buy food cheaper? You want to be Dutch.Jesuit Missions: Basically, think of a bunch of priests living on islands. There you go. They have no real alignment or ships, they just are there and sell food. Talk to them to help with your main quest to find your family.Pirate settlements: Like a regular city, but you can usually only get recruits and food here, but you can end up helping the pirate leader to take over cities.You do NOT have to side with anyone. Basically, the game allows you to have the freedom of you choosing the options to help anyone. I, personally, help the Dutch all the time (because it's actually easy if you are good with economic type of gameplay), but you could, for example, help the Dutch one time, help the English one time, help the Spanish once, then help the French, and have everyone love you.This game is amazing, and it has multiple minigames of fencing, land battles, ship battles, and, yes, dancing.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 28, 2016
												Stupidly fun pirates game. There's a main quest to follow, but you can ignore it if you'd like. There are lost cities to discover, treasure to be unburied, towns to be sacked! Work your way up to the number 1 pirate by defeating famous pirates (including Blackbeard!). It's a game of revenge and adventuring, but even a taste of romance as you dance your way through all the governor's daughters. Literally dancing, because there's a dancing minigame.One thing I particularly enjoyed about this game was the combination of real-time and turn-based strategy. Most of it's real-time, but oftentimes if you sack a town, you'll have to pit your pirates against their soldiers in a fun turn-based game (the only time that isn't the case is if your number of pirate greatly trumps their number of soldiers; then you'll just have a sword fight with the Captain of the Guards). It's a fun game with several levels of difficulty, plus you can start at different time periods, which will also help decrease or increase the difficulty of the game, so replayability is high.

Posted: April 15, 2015
												Played it way back when Blockbuster was still around on the original Xbox. It's aged, but still a very enjoyable experience.Graphics: 7/10 - Held up better than I would've expected.Gameplay: 8.5/10 - Solid ship battle mechanics, reaction-based swordplay, ship management, and even mutiny.Sound: 8/10 - Would've been an 8.5 or 9 but for whatever reason I still don't particularly like the ballroom tracks.Lasting Appeal: 9.5/10 - There are so many ways to play this game that you'll find yourself making new saves just to experience everything this game throws at you.Overall: 8/10 - One of my favorite original Xbox games.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 17, 2015
												Sidmeier's Pirates is a remake of an older version of the Game and ticks all the boxes right for doing so. Having said that. I have 10.5 hours in it and finished it - that said higher difficulties from the start are still open to me, as you are obligated to start at the easiest difficulty when you first start the game but you can during the game up the difficulty by 'dividing the loot'.It has several 'mini-games' including dancing/romancing governor daughters, attacking cities, and fighting on ships. These mini-games are not overly hard, but not too difficult that is just a breeze. As you can interspace them the way you want the mini-games are never bothersome, in my opinion.The atmosphere and humor of the game is its major selling point and as such it a good little game for a bit of relaxing. And with the difficulties, different starting eras, and starting proficiencies you can definately make it harder on yourself to get a more challenging experience should you wish it, but to me it does not seem as if it was created to make you have deep low and mountain peak highs, but rather a relaxing giggle.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												This is an old game, but I gotta say, it's a good one.I got the urge to play some kinda pirate simulation game a while back, and there has just been nothing out on the market like that of late, unless you're into Assassin's Creed.. which I'm not. (because Ubisoft.)  But I found this on sale for a few bucks.. and thought.. Ok.. Pirates.. Sid Meier.. sure, why not.  It was a good choice.Lots of things you can do..different goals you can try for.  The mechanics are somewhat simplistic.. I mean, it's a 2004 remake of a 1987 game, so you can't expect too much sophistication out of it..  But that said, if you're looking for something to swash your buckle.. (or would that be buckle your swash?), this'll do it.  The minigame mechanics for fencing and dancing are easy at the lowest difficulty, but get quite challenging at higher ones unless you've got good "twitch gamer" reflexes... So most of us will find a decent challenge available.The AI does some strange things at times.. that's pretty much to be expected..   Like in my latest playthrough, I decided to be a English pure "privateer".. following the terms of my "Letter of Marque and Reprisal"..  Drove the French and the Dutch completely out of the Caribbean, and the Spanish are down to just a half a dozen cities on the coast of Mexico and Central America..  The last French and Dutch cities to fall, and the last Spanish city on the northern islands, all responded by sending invasion force after invasion force, sometimes 3 or 4 frigates at once laden with troops.. over and over.. out of cities with barely any money or troops due to my blockade..  which, of course, would be impossible with any sense of "realism"..But that doesn't detract from the fun. In fact, it makes it even more amusing.. "How can I get the AI to freak out this time?" becomes it's own sort of meta-game.  At least for me. I personally would *love* to see a *sequel* to this game.. not a HD remake, or a relaunch.. but a full Pirates! 2.  Updated engine, graphics.. merging geopolitics into it a bit borrowing elements from the Civilization series.. Really treating the naval situation and piracy in the region during that time as it was historically... a proxy war between the competing empires of Europe..  Character development maybe, a skill tree, so you get better at your skills along with upgrading gear, instead of just getting bonuses from equipment..  More promotion options, etc..  The ability to have actual fleet combat, and the ability to found your own colonies...But probably the only actual real *downside* to this game.. is that I haven't figured out how to actually be the aggressor against a foreign city... the only way I've found so far is to just look and sink a whole bunch of their ships till the harbor guns get♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥enough to take a pot shot at you.. then you get the option to "attack"..  I wanna bombard em from sea, then unleash the pirate hordes.. lol..But even with that annoyance, and the limitations of this being a very old remake of an even older game.. it's a classic.. Revolutionary for it's time, and has aged quite well. Give it a try.

content:
Posted: October 24, 2015
												Ah Sid Meier how you love to make people waste their entire day away on just one video game. He does it well that's for sure, and Pirates (Next to civilization) Shows this better than anything. With this 2004 release being the best.Pros:-Very Piratey...Yohohoho.-Capturing, Plundering, and Digging up treasure never gets old.-The game let's you increase the difficulty the farther you get in the game-Restoring your family feels good-There's a good amount of upgrades-Pillaging Towns is the best part in my view. It acts as a Turn Bases Strategy, with some nice mechanics-You can Fight actual pirates like Black Beard.Cons:-If you can't control yourself while playing video games. Then STAY FAR AWAY! This game will take your entire life in a blink of an eye.-It's very tedious. If you can't stand grinding you will hate this game.-Dancing STINKS! If you don't have a good num pad then good luck trying to play that minigame.Overall if you like being a pirate then pick this up. Oh but remember something. The Spainish are the best to raid. (SO MUCH MONEY!)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 17, 2015
												A fun pirate game set in the Caribbean, during the 17th Century. You are a privateer looking to make his fortune and rescues if lost family. It is an early open world game, in that although there is a notional storyline, in practice you tend to end up sailing the seas, capturing or sinking ships with impunity whilst leaving your family to rot in captivity. The gameplay is not only confined to sailing the ocean blue, there is a host other (nefarious) activities to take part in, ranging from sacking cities and copious amounts of swordplay to wooing the daughters of cites governors with your masterful dancing skills. The controls are simple to pick up, although can hard to master are higher difficulty levels – a case in point is the dancing. At low difficulty you are given clear guides to which button to press. This becomes subtle hand gestures at higher levels, easy to miss as you stumble around the dancefloor like you have had too much grog. Graphically it is pretty to look at, without be Assassins Creed Black Flag. Bear in mind this was first released in 1987. It has been updated for modern OS but is still more functional than flashyGameplay	8Graphics	        6Control		7Fun		        8Overall		7.5

content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
												The tale of the Shipless pirate.it all started well, Mr. Sir. Captain. Reynaldo was a French Privateer raiding English and Spanish shipping he came to amass a small fortune in prizes and plunder he soon became famous and took on more crew, but soon things changed for the worse the French made peace with the spanish and the English merchants were all too scared to sail home. with the money stoping he soon took to darker pursuits, buying strange medicine from a myterious man in a backroom of a shady for 6000 Gold the men soon became worried for their captain, but more so for the loot. the spending was rampent, 3000 gold here a few thousand more there. soon the fortune he had spent years building was well deminished he resorted to outright Piracy to keep the crew in line. he started spinning tales to governors daughters dancing with them hoping to lead them on for more money to buy "exotic" and "mystical" items, but the crew finally agreed it was time for Mutiniy but just as it happened they suddenly came under fire, an English Pirate Hunter masking itself as french. the Crew returned fire a round of chain shot destroyed the main sail and the English promptly surrendered, a large amount of gold was plundered, and the Crew Mutinied taking the Gold and the Captains ship leaving him stranded on an Island.  Thus the final score is 10/10 would buy strange medicine from a mysterious man in a dark backroom of a Shady tavarn.

												I won a duel against the swordmaster, found a huge treasure and stole a valueable idol from the governor's mansion. Then I started my travels as a swashbuckling pirate and liked every minute of "Sid Meier's Pirates!". It's an awesome game which connects a lot of minigames like ship-to-ship-combat, sword-duels, dancing and town-sieging with the small but nice story of finding your family. Even though it is repetitive, there are different quests as you progress and setting the difficulty also affects the A.I.'s behaviour.

I've always known that a system like steam keeps full control of the titles it manages away from the purchaser, making situations like mine possible, but never thought it would actually happen.Now that I know anything I purchase has a serious chance of being arbitrarily stolen from me at a later date without warning I will be going without.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 24, 2015
												In this game you take a role of privateer or pirate. You can work for either English, French, Dutch or Spanish - or even for all of them if you time your actions well. There's constantly changing basic economic and political system where player's actions do affect on the bigger picture as well. You can sail, capture ships, fight pirates, trade, do missions, dance with governors daughters and so on. There's many goals to fullfill and many ways to play. Because there's different eras to choose from and the world is open, dynamic and reactive the gaming experience does change lot. There's also different difficulty levels which do have effect. Game's replayability value is quite high and you can get it cheaply, especially on sale. Technically speaking I have been playing this game for something like 30 years from it's early versions on Commodore 64. From those early days they have added more content and huge haul in graphics but the core is same. And it works. Still one of the best, if not best, pirate games there are.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 6, 2015
												I have always loved this game, it's a pretty simple game that isn't very challenging, but I love it.Pros:•Wont matter for a lot of people, butvery little mouse input needed, great for playing on the bus, or somewhere where I don't have an external mouse with my laptop•Graphics still hold decently well, the animations are a bit laughable, but the graphics don't hurt my eyes.•Very little story.  While the game does have a story, it doesn't push you into doing it at all, so your free to do whatever you want. Considdered a pro, because a lot of simular games like this force you to do the main storyline, and limit the open-world.Cons:•Some of the minigames can get a bit reppetitive. Dancing is very important in the game, but is not very fun, and I hate sneaking into towns. The most common ones like sword-fighting or ship battles stay fun.•Not very difficult. Even on swashbucking difficulty (the hardest one) the only thing I have trouble with is a few sword fights, but if you use the cutlass and taunt often, they aren't a problem.Overall, this game deffinetly is not for everyone. I have always loved this style of game, so it's easy for me to love this game. The game isn't very expensive, especially on sale, so I would whole-heartedly recomend picking it up if it looks even slightly appealing to you.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												This game holds up remarkably well, despite its age. The developers did an excellent job at picking an aesthetic that looks great within the limitations of mid 2000's hardware. The gameplay is solid and is remarkably glitch-free. I love that it includes real geography and historical pirates. It's a fun, whimsical, and colorful interpretation of the pirate mythos.I only have two complaints about the game. The first is that the ground combat is lacking and I feel like it could have been left out entirely. The second is that the game is involved in some historical revisionism in that it completely ignores slavery and the triangular trade. That said, neither of those stopped me from dropping 50 hours into a decade-old game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												This is an old game, but I gotta say, it's a good one.I got the urge to play some kinda pirate simulation game a while back, and there has just been nothing out on the market like that of late, unless you're into Assassin's Creed.. which I'm not. (because Ubisoft.)  But I found this on sale for a few bucks.. and thought.. Ok.. Pirates.. Sid Meier.. sure, why not.  It was a good choice.Lots of things you can do..different goals you can try for.  The mechanics are somewhat simplistic.. I mean, it's a 2004 remake of a 1987 game, so you can't expect too much sophistication out of it..  But that said, if you're looking for something to swash your buckle.. (or would that be buckle your swash?), this'll do it.  The minigame mechanics for fencing and dancing are easy at the lowest difficulty, but get quite challenging at higher ones unless you've got good "twitch gamer" reflexes... So most of us will find a decent challenge available.The AI does some strange things at times.. that's pretty much to be expected..   Like in my latest playthrough, I decided to be a English pure "privateer".. following the terms of my "Letter of Marque and Reprisal"..  Drove the French and the Dutch completely out of the Caribbean, and the Spanish are down to just a half a dozen cities on the coast of Mexico and Central America..  The last French and Dutch cities to fall, and the last Spanish city on the northern islands, all responded by sending invasion force after invasion force, sometimes 3 or 4 frigates at once laden with troops.. over and over.. out of cities with barely any money or troops due to my blockade..  which, of course, would be impossible with any sense of "realism"..But that doesn't detract from the fun. In fact, it makes it even more amusing.. "How can I get the AI to freak out this time?" becomes it's own sort of meta-game.  At least for me. I personally would *love* to see a *sequel* to this game.. not a HD remake, or a relaunch.. but a full Pirates! 2.  Updated engine, graphics.. merging geopolitics into it a bit borrowing elements from the Civilization series.. Really treating the naval situation and piracy in the region during that time as it was historically... a proxy war between the competing empires of Europe..  Character development maybe, a skill tree, so you get better at your skills along with upgrading gear, instead of just getting bonuses from equipment..  More promotion options, etc..  The ability to have actual fleet combat, and the ability to found your own colonies...But probably the only actual real *downside* to this game.. is that I haven't figured out how to actually be the aggressor against a foreign city... the only way I've found so far is to just look and sink a whole bunch of their ships till the harbor guns get♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥enough to take a pot shot at you.. then you get the option to "attack"..  I wanna bombard em from sea, then unleash the pirate hordes.. lol..But even with that annoyance, and the limitations of this being a very old remake of an even older game.. it's a classic.. Revolutionary for it's time, and has aged quite well. Give it a try.

content:
Posted: September 26, 2016
												Very enjoyable classic game. You get too sail around attacking pirates and or other nations (and even your own) ships as you please. You might even annoy a nation enough to attack you on sight, forcing you to fight the town you were trying to buy some food supplies from and install a new governor. If you dont feel like sinking every ship you see there is also dancing with governors daughters, sword fighting (both in the tavern under some circumstances, and on the deck of the ship if your ships get too close during a ship battle) and Trading. You can build up a fleet of powerful ships, you can hunt down the pirate captain that has taken your sister... you can be left stranded on some rocks for months on end...For a game of it's age it does not dissapoint, is very entertaining and has more elements to it than expected. The graphics are not bad and you can sink a lot of hours into it without noticing!Highly reccomended to everybody

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 26, 2016
												Fun game for traveling the sea as a pirate.  Attack and plunder ships from different nations, only use care not to continously attack the same nation vessels/cities, otherwise they will attack you on sight for some time.  If you get in good with the local mayor, you can begin courting his daughter based on a game of pressing the keys in time with her dance movement.  This dancing is similar to combat in the game, only with the combat, you want to press the key that counters the pirates attack, not the same attack.Also, if you court the daughter enough times, you can eventually marry her.  There are three levels of "hotness" for each daughter.  You should be able to tell which daughter of a town/city is the hottest and which one is mediocre (the amount of cleveage is a good indicator [except for one version of the Dutch daughter, you just have to look at her face and breast size to verify if she is the hot one or not]).When you obtain enough portions to complete a map, you can search the land for buried treasure or a missing family member.  You can also assault a town/city like this, switching to a strategy game of moving your troops around a grid.One problem I had with this game is the pirates you recruit for your ship.  They constantly become demanding for more and more goods.  If you hold on to the goods for too long, sailing from one location to another without constantly plundering goods, they may mutiny on you and take off with one of your ships.  This usually requires splitting up the loot and recruiting more sailors, which eats up time in the game and lets your character age more quickly.The second, and much worse problem, in the game is the game becomes too redundant.  You go to a port town, sell off your goods, recruit new sailors, plunder ships, and search for your missing family and buried treasure.  At first it is fun but does lose its appeal about half way through.I still enjoyed this game overall and would recommend playing it, especially if you can purchase the game with a Steam special sale price.
