number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 7, 2015
												I enjoy this game from time to time. It's a slow paced pirate game - achingly slow when it comes to sailing (there are ways to speed it up, but even when maxed speed it's achingly slow when you sail against the wind) where you basically sack towns, fight and collect ships and more or less do what you'd expect in a game based on pirates.The ship combat I like the most. It's all about nailing the enemy ship(s) hard enough to cripple their ability to fight back without doing so much damage that you sink them (lest you say goodbye to the loot on their ship - or the ship itself if you wanted to capture it for your fleet) all while taking into account angles and wind direction to keep your ship moving. There are a good number of ships but once fully upgraded they fall into 2 basic catagories: 1. Big ship. Holds a lot of health, crew and cannons.2. Small ship. Dodges everything much easier with small size, fast turning, and fast speed.Once you collide of course there's a boarding sword fight scene - the ship battle being to widdle each others' crew down before boarding or get the other to surrender. The more crew you have the more time you have - if one crew defeats the other before the sword fight you're in is over the winning crew takes the win. There are a couple of options for swords but they don't change the experience very drastically unless on higher difficulties. After the fight the winner takes the loser's ship (they'll either sink it or add it to their fleet).There's a few other things to the game too. Sailing and ship battles tend to take up almost all of the time I spend playing. The battles are not soul draining though - unless one ship runs and the similar speeds result in the chase going on about a literal minute or two of almost no stimulation (I prefered small fast ships because they cut out the speed problem more often than big ones). There are a few other parts though. Minigames as part of the game progression more or less; ballroom dancing with govenors' daughters to raise reputation with them, sword fighting resembles a combinarion of "Paper-Rock-Scissors" and Flash Cards, hide and seek style treasure hunting where you collect map peices and use them to find where to go, and city seiges which feel like turn based Overhead strategy game.The overhead city attack is actually a little fun too. Your crew make up 3 unit types. Officers, Pirates and Buckaneers. They play very simply. Officers and pirates melee attack like chess peices that all only move 1 space each on the board (with officers being stronger). The buckeneers can shoot from several spaces away for much weaker damage. Attacking from the back or sides deals a lot more. Diving into cover helps against their guns. Also the more one unit gets into a fight the weaker he is due to moral dropping. That's about it to the strategy. There are no buildings to create or making more units or anything. The enemy does have a pretty varied amount of unit types though (protip: If the enemy has horsemen go straight for a forest tile. Those suckers are OP outside of them but get cut a third of their strength in forests. If the enemy has indians get out of the forests).You pretty much do these things over and over. There's really no plot or story other than a little intro scene (well technically you hunt down family, but it's not very focused on). It's a reletively fun game when just chilling and wanting to pimp up a ship. I won't lie though... the slow parts are painful.

No crashes, no graphical glitches, nothing. And I played it plenty.The game is good, steam is crap.There are other titles that I'm tempted to purchase on steam, because they are interesting, and only available on steam. I've always known that a system like steam keeps full control of the titles it manages away from the purchaser, making situations like mine possible, but never thought it would actually happen.Now that I know anything I purchase has a serious chance of being arbitrarily stolen from me at a later date without warning I will be going without.

												All you need to know about Pirates.This game was released in a similar form in the early 1990's called Pirates Gold for Sega Genesis.One day I started playing in my crappy college apartment as my roomate was leaving to go home for the weekend.  I don't remember the following hours...and days.   What I do remember in startling clarity is the horror on my roomates face when he comes in the door and I am still perched on the same crappy directors chair in the same boxers and t-shirt with several plates of sandwich crumbs and empty pint glasses with dried kool-aid stains still playing the game I had started 3 days earlier to the exclusion of all else, even basic hygiene more advanced than using the toilet.Its just that good.10/10 would neglect all life functions in the manor of a useless junkie again.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2016
												Stupidly fun pirates game. There's a main quest to follow, but you can ignore it if you'd like. There are lost cities to discover, treasure to be unburied, towns to be sacked! Work your way up to the number 1 pirate by defeating famous pirates (including Blackbeard!). It's a game of revenge and adventuring, but even a taste of romance as you dance your way through all the governor's daughters. Literally dancing, because there's a dancing minigame.One thing I particularly enjoyed about this game was the combination of real-time and turn-based strategy. Most of it's real-time, but oftentimes if you sack a town, you'll have to pit your pirates against their soldiers in a fun turn-based game (the only time that isn't the case is if your number of pirate greatly trumps their number of soldiers; then you'll just have a sword fight with the Captain of the Guards). It's a fun game with several levels of difficulty, plus you can start at different time periods, which will also help decrease or increase the difficulty of the game, so replayability is high.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 26
												Sid Meier's Pirates is an interesting mix of genres presented in a sort of "proto-sandbox" fashion: players take on the role of a swashbuckler living during the 17th century "Golden Age of Piracy". You may pursue the in-game story of searching the Caribbean Sea for their lost family members, but the game does not push this object on you but every so often, meaning that players are fully free to disregard the main storyline in order to make their own distinct niche out of Caribbean life. These activities include ship navigation and exploration, land combat (presented as a turn-based strategy minigame, ala Civilization), and courting noblewomen (presented as a rhythm minigame).The graphics are colorful and have the right amount of cartoonishness to them, and the often upbeat soundtrack helps put a smile on my face every time I boot this game up. If any of this sounds interesting, I'd say to jump head-on into Sid Meier's Pirates, as I don't think a simple review conveys how much fun this game is, so much as sitting down and making of it what you will does. The seas are what you make of them!Also, for those of you who originally owned this game on CD like I did, Steam will be able to read and use your old save files!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
												This game...it's hard to describe it exactly in an overarching view.Let me go ahead and talk about the factions in this game.Spain: Huge amounts of land and ships, but the ships suck and the land cities are heavily guarded. Ships are usually huge, but slow, and have a huge amount of crew, but the ships seem like they are made out of cardboard. Has most cities in the game. Also, the Spanish are at war with everyone almost all the time.England: Sloops and Brigs as far as the eye can see! England has some of the fastest ships, and remember how I said the Spanish ships are made of cardboard? Well, the English cannons fire the equivalent of napalm in a ball when hitting a Spanish ship. Besides the Spanish, they have the most amount of cities, although most are islands and not on the mainland Americas.France: The French have some what I'd consider all around style of ships. They are a mix of ships and power, but they work. They have less than the English, but aren't doing the worst.Netherlands/Dutch: "Oh sweet almighty Jesus, we are screwed," is probably what you'd think if you were the Dutch king. Basically, the Dutch aren't exactly doing the best when it comes to amount of land or types of ships, but it's much easier to buy and sell in Dutch markets, as well as get promotions. Basically, you want more recruits and buy food cheaper? You want to be Dutch.Jesuit Missions: Basically, think of a bunch of priests living on islands. There you go. They have no real alignment or ships, they just are there and sell food. Talk to them to help with your main quest to find your family.Pirate settlements: Like a regular city, but you can usually only get recruits and food here, but you can end up helping the pirate leader to take over cities.You do NOT have to side with anyone. Basically, the game allows you to have the freedom of you choosing the options to help anyone. I, personally, help the Dutch all the time (because it's actually easy if you are good with economic type of gameplay), but you could, for example, help the Dutch one time, help the English one time, help the Spanish once, then help the French, and have everyone love you.This game is amazing, and it has multiple minigames of fencing, land battles, ship battles, and, yes, dancing.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2016
												I played this a lot years ago, and it's still very enjoyable.  It's a pirate simulator with gameplay broken into a series of mini-games.  Sailing, sword-fighting, dancing, and sneaking are each individual mini-games, most of them similar to quick time events, and there is a simple system for dealing with food, morale, crew, loot, and all that.  There's also a story but it's not very interesting.  It's weakness is a lack of depth.  You will get tired of it eventually, because it becomes quite repetetive after a while.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 26, 2016
												Fun game for traveling the sea as a pirate.  Attack and plunder ships from different nations, only use care not to continously attack the same nation vessels/cities, otherwise they will attack you on sight for some time.  If you get in good with the local mayor, you can begin courting his daughter based on a game of pressing the keys in time with her dance movement.  This dancing is similar to combat in the game, only with the combat, you want to press the key that counters the pirates attack, not the same attack.Also, if you court the daughter enough times, you can eventually marry her.  There are three levels of "hotness" for each daughter.  You should be able to tell which daughter of a town/city is the hottest and which one is mediocre (the amount of cleveage is a good indicator [except for one version of the Dutch daughter, you just have to look at her face and breast size to verify if she is the hot one or not]).When you obtain enough portions to complete a map, you can search the land for buried treasure or a missing family member.  You can also assault a town/city like this, switching to a strategy game of moving your troops around a grid.One problem I had with this game is the pirates you recruit for your ship.  They constantly become demanding for more and more goods.  If you hold on to the goods for too long, sailing from one location to another without constantly plundering goods, they may mutiny on you and take off with one of your ships.  This usually requires splitting up the loot and recruiting more sailors, which eats up time in the game and lets your character age more quickly.The second, and much worse problem, in the game is the game becomes too redundant.  You go to a port town, sell off your goods, recruit new sailors, plunder ships, and search for your missing family and buried treasure.  At first it is fun but does lose its appeal about half way through.I still enjoyed this game overall and would recommend playing it, especially if you can purchase the game with a Steam special sale price.

I booted the game, chose my name and the nation that I would steal my first ship from, and set sail. I am happy to say that this game has weathered the test of time very well and still holds a depth and replayability that many more modern games lack. Even ignoring my nostalgic feelings for the game, I feel compelled to recommend this game to everyone.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 29, 2015
												Sid Meier's: Pirates! is an amazing game. I highly enjoy playing it, and I most definitely recommend this game to others, especially to those who loves open world and RPG games.  This game has a lot of mechanics to play with, and the varieties are just endless! There is also some element of tactic and strategy: to get the wind on your side so you can sail faster than other ships, turning your ship to the right angle to bombard your enemies with cannon balls, and position your pirates and buccaneers at strategic positions to overwhelm ports and cities! Or you can just brute force everything, like ramming your ship into enemy ships and hack the captain to pieces! Works too! However, don't expect too much from the stories, as they are slightly repetitive and there isn't too much about the main story of the game. But I definitely recommended the game.Positive:-Lots of things you can do! Recruit crews, take other ships, chase down criminals, romance governors' daughters, find treasures, attack ports, and many more!-You can play the absolute balls out of this game. As if the main quests isn't long enough, you can do many other side quests, like hunting down notorious and famous pirates, hunting for treasure, and finding lost cities. You can also do things for your personal achievement, like becoming the most famed pirate and advancing through the ranks in a faction.Even then, you still can increase the difficulty and add more challenge! Or, you can just retire early, and divide the plunder with your crew.-Variety. There are many different kinds of ships that you can sail, be it a war sloop, a war galleon, a trade galleon, a simple indian canoe, and many more! Add various upgrades to your ship. Be nasty to the European kingdoms by wrecking their ships and sacking their ports, or rise through the ranks as the admiral of the European fleet! Hire (force them to join your crew by sinking the ship they were on and leaving them with no choice) various specialists to aid you in your journey. Choose a weapon to duel against your enemies!Negative:-The plot of Sid Meier's: PIrates! is not too rich. The story is quite repetitive, and may seem boring after a while. Tossing notorious pirates into the sea only to see them magically reappear alive and well while rising through the top 10 pirates list is not the smoothest of things.-Expect not HD high quality graphics. The graphics excellent considering the time when the game was made, and it is bright, cheery and colorful, but it is starting to show its age.-Gameplay might be repetitive after a while. Capturing ships over and over with no other things to do left gets boring. The mechanics of sailing and taking over ports are also dramatically simplified, and it is certainly no sailing simulator.Recommended, 9/10.

After having come back to steam after having spent a year or so not using it, then reinstalling it on my new machine, i find that this game has been disabled for linux.There were no issues whatsoever that I encountered in playing this game the first time round. No crashes, no graphical glitches, nothing. And I played it plenty.The game is good, steam is crap.There are other titles that I'm tempted to purchase on steam, because they are interesting, and only available on steam. I've always known that a system like steam keeps full control of the titles it manages away from the purchaser, making situations like mine possible, but never thought it would actually happen.Now that I know anything I purchase has a serious chance of being arbitrarily stolen from me at a later date without warning I will be going without.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												Although the game squarely qualifies as old now, I couldn't resist buying it given how much I played it years ago, and how powerful the memories of it.The story offers a simple and straightforward red thread to follow for completion, but leaves so much room for exploration, choices and personal characterization (or lack thereof) that it actually allows many replays without getting boring.The minigames are of course a bit repetitive, but that's not something that ever bothers me, especially since they're based on rhythm and reactivity. Only the slow sailing across the map got annoying after a while, and that's a feature; you're NOT supposed to cross over the whole ocean without pause or action.Basically, this game is a blast for any player who likes writing their own story.One day, I'll publish the epic chronicles of the dreaded legendary pirate who attacked and took over the whole Spanish Armada with his lone but glorious war canoe Croustibat! :D

content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												It might not be everyones cup of tea but if you played the original, you'll love it.Brand new players may not fall in love with it so easily though, but still......I got to dance with the ladies, chase down and duel notorious pirates, experience great naval fights between multiple ships, learn to fence on my toes, get blown to pieces by pirate hunting ships, assualt towns on foot, sneak into cities and hit guards in the back of the head with batons, receive promotions, experience 6 months in jail, find and dig up hidden treasures, help some monks and more...The game has greatly improved graphics and sounds and I enjoyed it for about 6 hours before it got a bit repetitive. I am sure though that it is more and issue with me in 2016 than the game itself.There aren't many pirate games out there to compare with but so if swashbuckling is your thing, this is probably the one you need.Njoy!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
												The game in its core is a collection of mini-games that all work towards a common goal and make it more than the sum of its parts. Lots of activities in the game, from sea battles, trading, "massive" town sieges, finding buried treasure and all the other pirate stuff you expect to do in a game with the name "Pirates!".There is something here for everyone I would say and you should really have it in your library. It is easy to jump in and out of and won't take a lots of time to enjoy it. The only thing I don't like about this game is that the movement and action keys are bound to the numpad, but with that said it does not take away from the game that much and you get used to it pretty quick. Overall, it is one of the best pirate themed games ever and it is dirt cheap, especially if on sale.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												Graphics: 5/10Sound: 4/10Mechanic: 5/10Story: 4/10Action: 8/10Originality: 6/10Lasting Fun: 4/10and all considering that this is a game from a totally different age of computer games.Quite a good and funny game but definitely not what you expect from a modern game any longer. The game was released in 1987 and kinda overhauled and re-released sometimes around 2004. Considering the age of even the later version graphics and game look pretty good. I bought it for about 4 bucks which is an ok price, but I would never have paid 10+ for it. This game is not a simulation, it's more an arcarde style action game where you sail around, sink ships of several factions or pirates, do some politics and a little trading and can go for treasure hunting as well. actually the game has all a good pirate game needs. Yet, the action becomes stale pretty fast. Trading is kind of tedious as it requires you to have large ships and go long distances. Sailing long distances is punished in the game as your crew is going to desert you faster than you can replace them. In the later game this seems to get much better, but getting there is not funny at all. You can use your small starting loop to easily take a full blown war galley as prize. But you will not have the men to maintain it for long, even if you have loads of gold. The game is pretty open to your actions, there is no fix chain of quests you have to follow, although there are very helpful quests. The information in the game and the presentation of your ships is bad. You do get zero info about the capacities of your ships (you can carry 60 guns in small ships, but you don't see easily how many guns get fired and how many are just cargo). There is no full size view of your ship in the menues (I wish I could have seen it in full size and rotating), no fluff info (ship type, tonnage, sails, guns, etc). Hunting pirates was a laugh, I brought down No. 1 from the list within my very first 15 minutes if gameplay. Orientation is hard sometimes when leaving harbour, the compass is pretty simple and yous camera view very narrow. Although many seem to have enjoyed the cartoonist fun style of the game I missed the feeling of grim and dangerous piracy. It feels a bit like playing pirate in your bath tub. Good for a moment but nothing that makes me remember it or want to proceed further. Nice but yesterday.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												Great game. I've played this late into the night only to wonder why it is suddenly becoming light outside, and why the birds are chirping... Surprise! It isn't night anymore, and I'm supposed to "get up" for work in two hours.Certain parts of the game (i.e. dancing) I've never been very good at, but you can pick up some good equipment from the ladies. There are some patches available that allow you to cheat these parts. Just use then at the risk of making the game far too easy.Ship combat is simple but enjoyable. The backstory of trying to rescue your family adds a reason to sailing around and pirating for years.Overall a great game, and it is still fun to play years later. Give it a try!

If you want a light-hearted pirate sim or maybe more of what Assassin's Creed IV started to introduce, this will definitely scratch that itch. Plus it's usually on sale for dirt cheap. What are you waiting for?

												Have you ever wanted to feel like a pirate? To pillage cities whose only crime was being Spanish? To do battle with some of the most famous pirates in history? To objectively judge women based on their appearance? To be a duke in four seperate empires while they are all at war with one another? Then, I've got a game for you! It's called Sid Meier's Pirates, which aside from becoming repetitive, is a terrific game that every swashbuckling player should at least try. And just look at that price, it's practically piracy in of itself!

content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
												The game in its core is a collection of mini-games that all work towards a common goal and make it more than the sum of its parts. Lots of activities in the game, from sea battles, trading, "massive" town sieges, finding buried treasure and all the other pirate stuff you expect to do in a game with the name "Pirates!".There is something here for everyone I would say and you should really have it in your library. It is easy to jump in and out of and won't take a lots of time to enjoy it. The only thing I don't like about this game is that the movement and action keys are bound to the numpad, but with that said it does not take away from the game that much and you get used to it pretty quick. Overall, it is one of the best pirate themed games ever and it is dirt cheap, especially if on sale.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 14
												I absolutely love this game, but take it with a grain of salt because I love every pirate game ever made. The main story was fairly engaging, the trading system is surprisingly fun, and the scripted fights are usually fun and visually cool (you can throw a guy out a window!). That said, on the higher difficulties ship battles, dances, and fights can become a huge trial to get through. A ton of aspects in the game rely on a sort of quicktime click x to do the right thing mechanic that is sometimes cool because it’s so simple but can get rather boring and frustrating after a while. If you’re interested in playing a pirate and exploring the world, then give this one a try. 8/10 best pirate game I’ve seen in a long time.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 25
												For an aging game it is still a very playable game, the game runs with no crashing on Windows 10.  The resolution is a bit low but still looks ok. The game play can be a bit same old but it can throw up a challenge every now and then to keep your interest.   The only two gripes I personally have is when in battle and your on the left of the enemy they can escape easily, you seem to not be able to go right as the wind stops you dead, annoying  but you can get around it by making sure your on the righthand side of the enemy before going in to battle.  The other bit I dont like is the dancing sequence to please the lady, boring and not enjoyable so I tend to not bother! however it is funny to make yourself fall around all over the place if you do it wrong on purpose but even then, once doing that is enough for one giggle.  If this game is on sale, this is a bargain and a must buy if your into pirate games as it is a good few hours of fun, however if at full price, I would not have bought this game, I'd definetly wait until it is on offer on steam.
